EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many SNOTEL sites reported between 8 and 13 inches of new snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought 6 to 9 inches of snow to the valleys of White Pine, southern Lander and southern Eureka counties. In the mountains, 8 to 15 inches of snow fell. The Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt also received 8 to 13 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 12 and 18 inches of snow fell in the Carson Range from near Incline Village (Diamond Peak ski area) south to Marlette Lake on the 20th. At Lake Tahoe level, the Glenbrook CO-OP site reported 9 inches of snowfall.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved from the eastern Pacific into the West on the 30th, bringing heavy snow and rain to the Carson Range/Sierra and western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The town of Eureka picked up 7 inches of snow and the Big Creek Summit SNOTEL reported 9 inches of snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought 6 to 9 inches of snow to the valleys of White Pine, southern Lander and southern Eureka counties. In the mountains, 8 to 15 inches of snow fell. The Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt also received 8 to 13 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Valley locations received 6 to 9 inches of snow while the mountains picked up 8 to 15 inches of snow. Some amounts included: 9 inches in the Ely area, 7 inches at McGill and 6 inches at Lund. The Great Basin National Park Visitors Center reported 15 inches of new snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought 6 to 9 inches of snow to the valleys of White Pine, southern Lander and southern Eureka counties. In the mountains, 8 to 15 inches of snow fell. The Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt also received 8 to 13 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to 10 inches of snow fell between Carson City and Minden-Gardnerville on the 30th, with 12 inches of snow in Double Springs (5 miles north of Topaz Lake). Power was knocked out per a report 3 miles NNE of Topaz Lake.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved from the eastern Pacific into the West on the 30th, bringing heavy snow and rain to the Carson Range/Sierra and western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds in the Las Vegas Valley knocked down at least two trees and one set of power lines, and threw a covered horse corral over a fence. About 4000 customers lost power. The peak gust was measured at McCarran Airport.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southwest winds ahead of an approaching cold front caused minor damage in the Las Vegas Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred 3 miles NE of Mount Charleston at 8818 feet.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southwest winds ahead of an approaching cold front caused minor damage in the Las Vegas Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most areas in the Reno-Carson City-Minden area recorded wind gusts of between 40 and 50 mph on the 8th. However, foothill areas along Interstate 580 south of Reno (very wind prone) reported wind gusts of 60 to 73 mph. The strong winds caused trees to be downed along with the spilling of large boulders onto a I-580 access road at the south end of Washoe Valley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm, subtropical tap brought heavy, wet snow to the high Sierra on the 8th and 9th. In the lee of the Sierra into far western Nevada, heavy rain and strong gusty winds were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mount Rose and Diamond Peak ski areas reported between 2 and 3 feet of heavy, wet snow on the 8th and 9th. South of highway 50, 14 inches was reported at the Daggett Pass Fire Station. Below 7,000 feet, 10 inches of snow fell in Incline Village down to 6,700 feet. Near Lake Tahoe level, precipitation fell mostly as rain.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm, subtropical tap brought heavy, wet snow to the high Sierra on the 8th and 9th. In the lee of the Sierra into far western Nevada, heavy rain and strong gusty winds were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice jam flooding was observed along Huntington Creek near Twin Bridges. Moderate rainfall over the past 48 hours caused a steady rise of water in Huntington Creek.  Large blocks of ice carried by the water created an ice jam that caused water to flow over Hamilton stage road and the Twin Bridges. Ice jams were reported along the creek for 2.5 miles upstream from Twin Bridges.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate rainfall over the past 48 hours caused a steady rise on Huntington Creek. Large blocks of ice carried by the water created an ice jam that caused water to flow out of the banks of Huntington Creek and over the Hamilton Stage road and over the Twin Bridges.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread wind gusts between 60 and 70 mph were noted on the north, west, and southwest sides of Reno as well as in portions of the Carson Valley. In the foothills along Interstate 580, wind gusts of 80 to 90 mph were recorded. The high winds brought a few fences down in Golden Valley and in Spanish Springs. In southwest Reno, small trees were uprooted along with some power outages.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through western Nevada early on the 16th. Ahead of the front on the 15th, strong winds occurred with the highest in the immediate lee of the Carson Range.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downslope winds ahead of the oncoming storm system briefly gusted to 60 mph 1 mile ESE of Red Rock Canyon.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought high winds, heavy rain, and heavy mountain snow to portions of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain in the Las Vegas Valley caused a power outage to 1263 customers; shorted out a railroad crossing sensor, causing the gate to block a major thoroughfare; and contributed to at least 43 vehicle crashes, resulting in eight injuries (indirect).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought high winds, heavy rain, and heavy mountain snow to portions of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: These gusts occurred 3 miles NE of Mt. Charleston.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought high winds, heavy rain, and heavy mountain snow to portions of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

CZ_NAME_STR: LINCOLN COUNTY EXCEPT THE SHEEP RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A sensor near Rachel measured a gust to 55 mph, and a spotter reported minor damage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought high winds, heavy rain, and heavy mountain snow to portions of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most areas in the Reno-Carson City area noted wind gusts between 40 and 50 mph early on the 6th. However, wind prone areas recorded wind gusts of 60 to 65 mph. Winds caused a 10 X 20 metal shed to come apart on the north side of Carson City and cause damage to a vehicle. An NDOT observation about 1/4 mile northwest of the damage recorded a wind gust to 63 mph at 545PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front brought gusty winds to the Reno-Carson City area on the 6th, with some wind damage in Carson City.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two outbuildings were destroyed and around 15 trees were uprooted as a cold front moved through Hidden Valley. Also, a 2 X 4 from one of the outbuildings was driven into the side of a home. A wind gust to 52 mph was recorded at the UNR Ag Farm about a half-mile northeast of the damage site. However, based on wind studies for the enhanced Fujita scale regarding the uprooting of coniferous trees a much higher speed was estimated at the damage site.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the Reno area on the morning of the 10th. Most areas experienced wind gusts of 35 to 45 mph, however winds were much stronger in localized areas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 63 mph was observed at the Stag Mountain RAWS, 62 mph at the Long Hollow RAWS, and 58 mph at the O'Neil NDOT mesonet site.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought wind gusts up to 87 mph across northern Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 87 mph was observed at the Ruby Valley NDOT mesonet site, 78 mph at the Pequop Summit NDOT mesonet site, 72 mph at the Warm Springs NDOT mesonet site, and 62 mph at the Wells/Moor Grade NDOT site.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought wind gusts up to 87 mph across northern Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 64 mph was observed at the Pilot Peak NDOT mesonet site, and a gust to 63 mph at the Spring Gulch RAWS.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought wind gusts up to 87 mph across northern Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred near Red Rock Canyon.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Pacific storm system brought strong downslope winds in the lee of the Sierra Nevada and Spring Mountains, and also brought high winds to the western Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak gust was measured 3 miles NE of Mt. Charleston at 2234 PST on the 29th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system brought locally high winds to the Mojave Desert.
A winter like storm brought heavy snow to the Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range. Most SNOTEL's reported 7 to 11 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred 40 miles E of Beatty.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system brought locally high winds to the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most areas saw wind gusts to between 40 and 50 mph early on the 22nd. However, the Galena RAWS and Reno-Tahoe airport noted wind gusts between 60 and 66 mph, along with sustained winds over 40 mph for the airport from 0018PST to 0143PST. While wind speeds decreased later in the morning, erratic wind shifts near the front (around 0730PST) at the Reno airport led to low level wind shear and major concerns for the airport (although no incidents were noted). Finally, a large part of a tree was broken in Sparks early in the morning.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through western Nevada on the morning of the 22nd, bringing high winds followed by low level wind shear to the Reno-Tahoe airport as well as some damage in Sparks.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak gust was measured 5 miles NW of Dyer at 1200 PST. Visibility was briefly near zero in blowing dust.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific storm system brought a short period of high winds to portions of the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds to south-central Elko County. Observed wind gusts included 70 mph at the Ruby Valley NDOT mesonet site, 67 mph at the Warm Springs NDOT mesonet site, 64 mph at the Ruby Lake RAWS, and 58 mph at the Pequop Summit NDOT mesonet site.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front produced high winds across portions of eastern Nevada. Wind gusts up to 70 mph were observed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front produced high winds across White Pine county. Observed wind gusts included 69 mph at the Ely CEMP site, 63 mph at the North Spring Valley DRI site, and 58 mph at both the Ely ASOS site and the Baker NDOT mesonet site.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front produced high winds across portions of eastern Nevada. Wind gusts up to 70 mph were observed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak gust was measured 3 miles NE of Mount Charleston at 1234 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific storm system brought a short period of high winds to portions of the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front produced high winds across southeastern Elko county. Wind gusts to 62 mph were reported at the Pilot Peak Junction NDOT mesonet site and at the Spring Gulch RAWS site.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front produced high winds across portions of eastern Nevada. Wind gusts up to 70 mph were observed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fire which started outdoors spread to two houses due to strong winds. No one was injured, but both homes were damaged.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific storm system brought a short period of high winds to portions of the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak gust was measured 40 miles E of Beatty at 1315 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought a period of high winds to the Mojave Desert and nearby areas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow was reported across southern Lander and southern Eureka counties. Reports included 13 inches at the Big Creek Summit SNOTEL, 10 inches at both the Diamond Peak and Vacarro SNOTEL sites, and nearly 5 inches in Eureka.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter-like storm brought heavy snow to southern Lander and southern Eureka counties. SNOTEL sites reported between 10 and 13 inches of snow and a COOP observer in Eureka reported nearly 5 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A two foot diameter tree was snapped about 40 feet above the ground at Floyd Lamb State Park.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought a period of high winds to the Mojave Desert and nearby areas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak gust occurred 44 miles ENE of Beatty at 1800 PST. Dust storm conditions were also reported by a spotter in Dyer.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds to much of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

CZ_NAME_STR: LINCOLN COUNTY EXCEPT THE SHEEP RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds blew down several large tree limbs at Cathedral Gorge State Park. The event time is estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds to much of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust was measured 5 miles NW of Pahrump.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds to much of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred 1 mile ESE of Red Rock Canyon.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds to much of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two trampolines became airborne, trees blew down into roads, seriously damaging at least one car, several canopies at Planet Hollywood blew into the street, a carport at an apartment complex tipped over, and about 18,000 customers lost power.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds to much of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

CZ_NAME_STR: LAKE MEAD/LAKE MOHAVE NATIONAL RECREATION AREA (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the Callville Bay area, damage included 17 house trailer skirts; nine trailer awnings; several trailer roofs; flying debris damage to some vehicles, one houseboat, and a dock; a 25 foot sailboat which was flipped off a trailer; and damage to NV Energy infrastructure. At the Las Vegas Boat Harbor, one dock was pushed 20 feet and the bridge leading to it was damaged. Two other docks and private boats were also damaged. One man was presumed drowned in Lake Mead after high winds blew away his boat and caused waves in the lake.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds to much of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A photo was taken of the tornado. A storm survey was completed and the only evidence of a tornado was some debris stuck in a fence along the path of the tornado.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm moving form east to west across Elko produced two EF0 tornadoes. The first tornado touched down on Manzanita Lane behind JC Penny's. A photo was taken of the tornado. No damage was reported besides some debris stuck in a fence along the tornado's path.  ||The second tornado touched down on Aspen Way near the Post Office. It uprooted a large tree. The tornado then moved into the Smith's parking lot where it tore some shingles off a car wash and tossed shopping carts into the air.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado touched down along Aspen Way near the Post Office. It uprooted a large tree and snapped off multiple branches along Aspen Way. The tornado then moved into the Smith's parking lot where it torn off a five by twenty foot section of shingles from the car wash. It also lifted shopping carts into the air. One shopping car slammed into the back of a vehicle causing some damage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm moving form east to west across Elko produced two EF0 tornadoes. The first tornado touched down on Manzanita Lane behind JC Penny's. A photo was taken of the tornado. No damage was reported besides some debris stuck in a fence along the tornado's path.  ||The second tornado touched down on Aspen Way near the Post Office. It uprooted a large tree. The tornado then moved into the Smith's parking lot where it tore some shingles off a car wash and tossed shopping carts into the air.
A thunderstorm produced penny to nickle size hail on the west side of Elko.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado was photographed near Horse Mountain. A storm survey was conducted but no damage was found. However survey efforts were hampered by steep and rugged terrain.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tornado was photographed near Horse Mountain. A storm survey was conducted but steep and rugged terrain hampered survey efforts. No damage was found.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A significant amount of water over state road 121 was reported by NDOT. There was  also rock and dirt debris with the fast-flowing water which caused the closure of the road. The time of the flash flood was estimated based on radar as the reports were received after the actual event.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms over central Nevada developed and moved west during the afternoon and evening of the 22nd. In addition to localized heavy rain, thunderstorm outflows pushed into western Nevada in the evening bringing a significant dust storm to some areas between Reno and Fernley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An image from highway 447 between Fernley and Nixon and a report of visibility less than 1/4 mile in Fernley confirmed a dust storm west of Lovelock and Fallon. The dust was carried by large-scale thunderstorm outflows which brought east to northeast winds of 15-25 mph with gusts to 40 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms over central Nevada developed and moved west during the afternoon and evening of the 22nd. In addition to localized heavy rain, thunderstorm outflows pushed into western Nevada in the evening bringing a significant dust storm to some areas between Reno and Fernley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread visibility less than 1/4 mile were reported in the Reno area and east to around Fernley. The dust was carried by large-scale thunderstorm outflows bringing east to northeast winds of 15-25 mph with gusts to 40-50 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms over central Nevada developed and moved west during the afternoon and evening of the 22nd. In addition to localized heavy rain, thunderstorm outflows pushed into western Nevada in the evening bringing a significant dust storm to some areas between Reno and Fernley.

Very dry surface air brought exceptionally high-based (some above 12,000 ft AGL) showers and thunderstorms to western Nevada on the 2nd. Even apparently weak showers brought outflow winds over 50 mph to some areas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two people died of heat related causes in the Las Vegas Valley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two people died of heat related causes in the Las Vegas Valley.
A dry microburst produced a wind gust to 60 mph at the Austin RAWS site.
A dry microburst produced a wind gust to 67 mph at the Desatoya Mountain RAWS site.
A dry microburst produced a wind gust to 60 mph at the Eureka Airport ASOS.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A dry microburst just east of the Eureka Airport destroyed a hay barn and uprooted a large tree. Winds were estimated at 65 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dry microburst just east of the Eureka Airport destroyed a hay barn and uprooted a large tree.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds knocked a large tree down onto another tree in the old town area of Mount Charleston.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season storm system brought isolated high winds to the mountains of southern Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire in Pahrump burned two sheds, a mobile home, and two motor homes, displacing four families. Two volunteer firefighters also suffered heat exhaustion in the 109 degree temperature.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three wildfires broke out in southern Nevada, destroying several structures and vehicles before being contained.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high temperature reached 112F at McCarran Airport in Las Vegas.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached in Las Vegas on July 1st, and nearly reached on the 2nd and 3rd. Four people died of heat related causes during this period - three in Las Vegas and one in Death Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust measured at Little Valley RAWS. Gust between 1438 and 1538PST...exact time of gust estimated from radar.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures and a very dry sub-cloud layer led to isolated, high-based showers and thunderstorms with very strong outflow winds on the 1st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust at the Five Mile Flat NDOT sensor. The gust was caused by an outflow from earlier thunderstorms to the south of the sensor.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures and a very dry sub-cloud layer led to isolated, high-based showers and thunderstorms with very strong outflow winds on the 1st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Outflow from earlier thunderstorms to the south of the Reno-Tahoe International airport brought this gust.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures and a very dry sub-cloud layer led to isolated, high-based showers and thunderstorms with very strong outflow winds on the 1st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports of large tree limbs downed along Sparks Blvd. and at the Sparks Marina.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures and a very dry sub-cloud layer led to isolated, high-based showers and thunderstorms with very strong outflow winds on the 1st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust at NWS Reno office. Gust caused by large outflow from earlier thunderstorms well south of office.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures and a very dry sub-cloud layer led to isolated, high-based showers and thunderstorms with very strong outflow winds on the 1st.

CZ_NAME_STR: LINCOLN COUNTY EXCEPT THE SHEEP RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cottonwood Fire and Middle Ridge Fire were started by lightning near the Utah state line. The fires destroyed two cabins and a trailer home and damaged a cemetery. Beaver Dam State Park was also closed for a time due to the fires.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three wildfires broke out in southern Nevada, destroying several structures and vehicles before being contained.
A dry microburst produced a wind gust to 59 mph at the Ruby Lake RAWS site.
A dry microburst produced a wind gust to 58 mph at the Alligator Ridge RAWS site.
A dry microburst produced a wind gust to 59 mph at the Combs Canyon RAWS site.
A dry microburst produced a wind gust to 68 mph at the Alligator Ridge RAWS site.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Outflow winds from distant thunderstorms beached two boats, including one house boat.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first seasonal push of monsoon moisture fueled an outbreak of thunderstorms across the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin. Many storms produced severe weather and flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first seasonal push of monsoon moisture fueled an outbreak of thunderstorms across the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin. Many storms produced severe weather and flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred at Sierra Vista High School.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to 12 inches of water flowed over Durango Drive at and north of Blue Diamond Road. The Blue Diamond Channel ALERT recorded 1.10 inches of rain in 30 minutes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first seasonal push of monsoon moisture fueled an outbreak of thunderstorms across the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin. Many storms produced severe weather and flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds over Lake Mead triggered swells up to eight feet that sank at least one vessel. 11 people had to be rescued.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first seasonal push of monsoon moisture fueled an outbreak of thunderstorms across the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin. Many storms produced severe weather and flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One woman died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One woman died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached in Las Vegas as the high temperature reached 112F.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust was measured at the Kane Springs RAWS.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lingering monsoon moisture brought isolated severe weather and flash flooding to the eastern Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured at the NWS office in Reno.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures bring very high-based thunderstorms with strong outflow winds on the 14th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck and set fire to two palm trees.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lingering monsoon moisture brought isolated severe weather and flash flooding to the eastern Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported that highway 359 south of Hawthorne and Lucky Boy Pass Road were closed due to flash flooding/debris flows. At least one vehicle was stranded in mud. A video was shared on Facebook showing fast-flowing water over highway 359.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving thunderstorms brought heavy rain and localized flash flooding to Mineral County on the 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water and debris flowed onto state highway 376 and the Department of Highways had to clear the debris from the roadway. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding across portions of northern Nye county. In the town of Tonopah 1 to 1.5 feet of water flowed through main street. Water and debris were reported flowing across the road on State Route 376 north of Tonopah. Water and debris was also reported flowing across the road 3 miles south of Hadley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused water and debris to flow across State Highway 376 from mile marker 7 to 14. Shoulders were damaged. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding across portions of northern Nye county. In the town of Tonopah 1 to 1.5 feet of water flowed through main street. Water and debris were reported flowing across the road on State Route 376 north of Tonopah. Water and debris was also reported flowing across the road 3 miles south of Hadley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from a thunderstorm caused flash flooding in the town of Tonopah. Water 1 to 1.5 feet deep flowed down main street. Water seeped into one business in downtown. Some asphalt was lifted at a Shell gas station. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding across portions of northern Nye county. In the town of Tonopah 1 to 1.5 feet of water flowed through main street. Water and debris were reported flowing across the road on State Route 376 north of Tonopah. Water and debris was also reported flowing across the road 3 miles south of Hadley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water up to six inches deep flowed through the Rainbow Canyon subdivision.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lingering monsoon moisture brought isolated severe weather and flash flooding to the eastern Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One man died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One person died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail report near Carson City High School.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderately high atmospheric moisture with slow-moving thunderstorms brought heavy rain and isolated severe thunderstorms from the 19th through the 21st. Extensive damage from flash floods and debris flows was reported in Douglas County and Carson City on the 20th. In addition, a large dust storm occurred on the 20th.

Moderately high atmospheric moisture with slow-moving thunderstorms brought heavy rain and isolated severe thunderstorms from the 19th through the 21st. Extensive damage from flash floods and debris flows was reported in Douglas County and Carson City on the 20th. In addition, a large dust storm occurred on the 20th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Homeowner called 911 to report water flowing into his home at 1319PST. At least 5 other homes indicated mud (up to 3 to 5 feet) and water flows, with a video showing fast-flowing water down a street.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderately high atmospheric moisture with slow-moving thunderstorms brought heavy rain and isolated severe thunderstorms from the 19th through the 21st. Extensive damage from flash floods and debris flows was reported in Douglas County and Carson City on the 20th. In addition, a large dust storm occurred on the 20th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported debris and rocks in roadways near Windmill and Fish Springs Road around 1400PST. A short time later the spotter noted that Windmill Road was washed out and Calle Del Sol was impassable. The spotter's rain gauge recorded 1.10 of rain between 1300PST and 1325PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderately high atmospheric moisture with slow-moving thunderstorms brought heavy rain and isolated severe thunderstorms from the 19th through the 21st. Extensive damage from flash floods and debris flows was reported in Douglas County and Carson City on the 20th. In addition, a large dust storm occurred on the 20th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum wind gust measured at the Dead Camel RAWS between 1347PST and 1447PST. Time of gust estimated from radar.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water over roads and mud debris along and near Center Drive were reported (including pictures and videos) by a fire department official. Extensive damage to streets due to undermining was noted along with minor water and mud intrusions into several homes. One home had up to a foot of water and mud in the garage along with damage to the garage door. The time of the event is estimated.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms initiated an extensive gust front, which moved north bringing winds 25 to 40 mph with gusts to around 60 mph. The Pershing County Sheriff's office (as well as photographic evidence) indicated a large dust storm with near zero visibility along highway 95 north of Fallon and on Interstate 80 between Fernley and Winnemucca.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One man died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One person died of heat related causes on July 22nd, and Las Vegas reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria on July 23rd.

A thunderstorm produced a wind gust to 79 mph near Warm Springs.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding covered several lanes of Interstate 15 near Jean, forcing traffic into the median. Highway 161 from Jean to Goodsprings was closed, and rocks and mud also washed onto secondary roads.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a short dry spell, another push of monsoon moisture fueled more thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert, some of which produced flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Major flash flooding occurred downstream of the Carpenter One burn area. Water and debris five feet deep came down Rainbow Canyon. Six homes were damaged, including two with major damage. Rainbow Canyon Road was damaged, as were utility lines and a water pipe.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a short dry spell, another push of monsoon moisture fueled more thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert, some of which produced flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Elko Daily Free Press relayed report of flash flooding on Elburz road. Called and spoke with spotter who said  3 feet of  water and debris flowed across the road. Road was damaged  and fence destroyed. Damages estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused 3 feet of water and debris to flow across Elburz Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail covered the ground and was found 1 to 1.5 hours later.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning set fire to a palm tree.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water and mud several feet deep along the shoulder of Highway 93 about 35 miles south of Wells. Time and damages estimated. NWS Storm Survey completed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused water and debris several feet deep along Highway 93 about 35 miles south of Wells.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado was seen touching down just north of the Barrick Goldstrike Mine and then moved across a burn scar caused by a rangeland fire the previous day. The tornado moved mainly west to east with a path 1/2 mile long and 20 feet wide causing brush debris to rise up to 15 feet into the air. Winds were estimated up to 80 mph. The tornado was confirmed through a NWS and Barrick Goldstrike Mine survey.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An EF0 tornado touched down just north of the Barrick Goldstrike Mine. It stayed on the ground for around 1/2 mile and was about 20 feet wide. It traversed a rural area and the only damage was to native vegetation.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred along rural roadways. Debris flows were observed. Damages estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding along rural roadways about 14 miles southwest of Contact.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway 322 was closed due to flooding from mile marker 5 to the Rose Valley turnoff. A portion of the road was washed out.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: County road 728 had shoulder damage and debris over the road. Time and damage estimated.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A piece of metal roof was torn off a shed and damage to a satellite receiver was also noted. The metal shed doors were also blown in. Estimated winds of 60 to 70 mph from  a microburst. NWS storm survey conducted. Damages estimated.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported that Pine Nut Creek was flooding near Lena Lane. The Minden-Gardnerville Record Courier received a report from the owner of City of Refuge (just downstream from Lena Ln) indicating flooding of the property's orchards. One home was flooded on Blue Sage Rd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain in the Pine Nut Range near the headwaters of Pine Nut Creek caused substantial flash flooding east of the Allerman Canal (in Gardnerville) along Pine Nut Creek.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Minden-Gardnerville Record Courier noted that a Douglas County fire marshal stated that 9 houses had interior damage due to flooding. Also, emergency officials indicated that 2 feet of water had flowed over Fish Springs Rd. A power pole was broken near Jacobsen Ln due to the flash flood.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain in the Pine Nut Range near the headwaters of Pine Nut Creek caused substantial flash flooding east of the Allerman Canal (in Gardnerville) along Pine Nut Creek.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flood waters from Pine Nut Creek moved over East Valley Rd (and several non-paved roads) per photographic evidence.  The Allerman Canal (eastern side of Gardnerville) helped to stop the advance of flood waters. The time of the flash flood is estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain in the Pine Nut Range near the headwaters of Pine Nut Creek caused substantial flash flooding east of the Allerman Canal (in Gardnerville) along Pine Nut Creek.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This wind gust was measured at a Citizen Weather Observer Program (CWOP) site.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved into northern California on the 11th and 12th, aiding in the development of strong to severe thunderstorms. Some storms dropped very heavy rain (for western NV) with between 0.75 and 1.50 inches of rain in 20 to 30 minutes. The Nevada Department of Emergency Management estimated 2.43M in total damage in Douglas County from several flash flooding events in July and August (through the 11th), with damages split between public infrastructure (around 927K) and private residences (1.5M).

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Major flash flooding affected the Moapa, Logandale, and Mesquite areas. Several local roads were washed out and some were covered with five feet of silt. At least 20 homes were damaged and many people were evacuated. Parts of the Union Pacific railroad track were washed out. The parking lot of a power generating plant was filled with six feet of flood water. Interstate 15 suffered major damage and was closed for days. Cars floated down the highway, and one person was injured when he jumped in to help the occupants of a minivan which was swept over a 10-15 foot drop. Four earthen dams were breached in the area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major surge of monsoon moisture aided by Hurricane Norbert just west of Baja California fueled an outbreak of thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin. Widespread flash flooding occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Major flash flooding occurred in Taylor Canyon along State Highway 226. Water up to 5 feet deep covered the highway and washed boulders 2 to 3 feet in diameter onto the road. Six travel trailers and a single wide mobile home were partially submerged. Multiple car were submerged and several moved by the water. At least 1 swift water rescue was conducted. A local business, garage, and homes were inundated with several feet of mud and water. Damages estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused major flash flooding in Taylor Canyon along State Highway 226. Five feet of water was reported on the highway with boulders 2 to 3 feet in diameter washed onto the road.  On State Highway 278 south of Carlin 2 feet of water flowed across the highway.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain resulted in 2 feet of water flowing across state route 278 about 6 miles south of  Carlin. Damages estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused major flash flooding in Taylor Canyon along State Highway 226. Five feet of water was reported on the highway with boulders 2 to 3 feet in diameter washed onto the road.  On State Highway 278 south of Carlin 2 feet of water flowed across the highway.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds were recorded in the foothills around Reno, at the Reno airport and in portions of the north valleys of Reno on the 14th and 15th. The Galena RAWS and Five Mile Flat NDOT sensors had the highest wind gusts (81 and 77 mph, respectively), with gusts up to 68 mph at the Stead airport and 61 mph at the Reno-Tahoe International Airport. Sporadic power outages were noted on the 14th and 15th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure over the Pacific moved into California and Oregon early on the 15th, bringing strong winds to the Reno area from the evening of the 14th through the morning of the 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This event occurred 40 miles east of Beatty.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front brought gusty winds to much of southern Nevada, with brief, isolated high winds observed on the Nevada National Security Site.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong north winds blew through the Las Vegas Valley in the wake of a cold front. A large tree was uprooted and fell on a house near the intersection of Vegas Drive and Michael Way. The North Las Vegas Airport measured a gust to 52 mph around the time that the tree blew down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front brought strong winds to much of the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High wind gusts were recorded at various sites late in the evening of the 28th into the early morning hours of the 29th. The highest wind gust (81 mph) was recorded at the Galena RAWS, with many other sites noting wind gusts between 60 and 70 mph. Winds caused a tree near downtown Reno to snap near its base and cause minor damage to a home.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through the Reno-Carson City-Minden area on the 29th, with a short period of high winds late on the 28th and early on the 29th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rain in the Las Vegas Valley contributed to 30 vehicle accidents with 18 minor injuries.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system brought rain and snow to much of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin on the 2nd. The leftover moisture and colder air in the wake of the storm produced patchy dense fog on the 3rd and 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense fog caused the Red Rock Scenic Loop to be closed for nearly 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system brought rain and snow to much of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin on the 2nd. The leftover moisture and colder air in the wake of the storm produced patchy dense fog on the 3rd and 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense fog at McCarran Airport in Las Vegas caused some flights to be cancelled and many more to be delayed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system brought rain and snow to much of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin on the 2nd. The leftover moisture and colder air in the wake of the storm produced patchy dense fog on the 3rd and 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread wind gusts over 65 mph were noted on the 11th, with the highest gusts (over 80 mph) west of highway 395 in the foothills and the southwestern Carson Valley. There were an exceptionally high number of damage reports including power lines and trees downed (knocking out power to more than 10,000), fences damaged, and a semi-truck blown over on Interstate 80. In addition, winds caused more than 30 flight cancellations at the Reno-Tahoe International airport.  Damages from this event are a rough estimate.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure approaching the northern California coast brought widespread wind damage to the Lake Tahoe and the Reno-Carson City-Minden areas on the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Glenbrook and Dagget Pass Fire Stations responded to numerous incidents of fallen trees and downed power lines due to high winds between Cave Rock and Kingsbury Grade. One tree fell onto a house resulting in major damage, with at least 7 homes damaged in all. A small fire was noted due to a downed power line north of Cave Rock.|Winds gusted between 45-70 mph below 7,500 feet, with a gust to 112 mph atop Slide Mountain. Damages from this event are a rough estimate.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure approaching the northern California coast brought widespread wind damage to the Lake Tahoe and the Reno-Carson City-Minden areas on the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds ahead of an approaching storm system gusted up to 62 mph and caused roof damage in Austin. A roof was blown off a house in Austin and numerous shingles were blown off other homes. Reported wind gusts included: 62 mph at the Reese River Valley DRI mesonet site, 60 mph at both the Austin RAWS site and the Eureka Airport ASOS.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds ahead of an approaching storm system blew a roof off a home in Austin and numerous shingles off other homes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Isolated high winds occurred at Indian Springs (KINS) ahead of the main band of rain.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another storm system brought locally high winds, rain and snow, and patchy dense fog to the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated eight to 10 inches of snow fell at Lida Summit, with two to three inches in Goldfield. Highway 266 was closed for a time until plows could clear it.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another storm system brought locally high winds, rain and snow, and patchy dense fog to the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer on Mount Charleston measured eight inches of snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another storm system brought locally high winds, rain and snow, and patchy dense fog to the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A NWS employee reported patchy dense fog along the 215 Beltway, with visibility near zero at the Charleston exit.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another storm system brought locally high winds, rain and snow, and patchy dense fog to the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds ahead of a strong storm system gusted up to 71 mph. Winds gusts included: 71 mph at the Texas Springs RAWS, 65 mph at the Double H RAWS, 60 mph at the Morey Creek RAWS, and 59 mph at the Winnemucca airport.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Winds ahead of a strong storm system gusted up to 71 mph across Humboldt county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought heavy snow to the Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range. Amounts included: 19 inches at the Green Mountain SNOTEL, 16 inches at the American Beauty SNOTEL, 15 inches at the Smith Creek SNOTEL, 14 inches at the Lamoille #3 SNOTEL, and 9 inches at the Trout Creek Upper SNOTEL.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought 6 to 9 inches of snow across portions of southern Lander and southern Eureka counties, and up to 19 inches in the Ruby Mountains.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to portions of southern Lander and southern Eureka counties. Snowfall amounts included: 9 inches at both the Big Creek Summit SNOTEL and the Vacarro Spring SNOTEL, and 6 inches in Austin.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought 6 to 9 inches of snow across portions of southern Lander and southern Eureka counties, and up to 19 inches in the Ruby Mountains.

CZ_NAME_STR: LINCOLN COUNTY EXCEPT THE SHEEP RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One to two inches of snow at Oak Springs Summit on Highway 93 (11 miles W of Caliente) led to several vehicles sliding off the road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Pacific storm system and associated cold front brought snow to the higher terrain of the southern Great Basin and locally high winds to the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds were measured 44 miles ENE of Beatty. The peak gust occurred at 0245 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Pacific storm system and associated cold front brought snow to the higher terrain of the southern Great Basin and locally high winds to the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Half a tree blew down across the intersection of Lamb and Washington in Las Vegas.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Pacific storm system and associated cold front brought snow to the higher terrain of the southern Great Basin and locally high winds to the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread 1 to 2 inches of snow fell in the Reno and Carson City-Minden areas during the early morning of the 30th. However, a band of heavier snow with 3 to 5 inches was reported in south and southwest Reno as well as in Virginia City and Carson City. Locally higher amounts of more than 6 inches were noted in the Palomino Valley near Pyramid Lake, likely caused by lake effect enhancement.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure dropped from British Columbia to western Nevada between the 29th and 30th, bringing a light to moderate snowfall to the Reno and Carson City area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One man died of hypothermia in Las Vegas.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very cold storm system brought rare low elevation snow to the Mojave Desert.

CZ_NAME_STR: LAKE MEAD/LAKE MOHAVE NATIONAL RECREATION AREA (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: About one inch of snow fell in Boulder City. A trace of snow fell as low as Alan Bible Visitor Center at Lake Mead.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very cold storm system brought rare low elevation snow to the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One inch of snow was reported in Searchlight and also near Cal-Nev-Ari, forcing the closure of Highway 95 for about three hours. Several vehicle crashes were reported in the Searchlight area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very cold storm system brought rare low elevation snow to the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trace of snow fell in most parts of Las Vegas.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very cold storm system brought rare low elevation snow to the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: McCarran Airport in Las Vegas measured 0.46 inch of rain, breaking the daily rainfall record. Law enforcement responded to 143 vehicle crashes, resulting in 43 (indirect) injuries. A total of 5000 customers also lost power.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably warm Pacific storm system brought rain to the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense fog forced the closure of the Red Rock Scenic Loop in Red Rock Canyon.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cooling temperatures overnight after light rain the previous evening led to isolated dense fog over the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rain in the Las Vegas Valley resulted in 50 vehicle crashes, with nine (indirect) injuries.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Pacific storm system brought rain to the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread wind gusts of 60 to 79 mph were recorded from Minden north to the Palomino Valley (southwest of Pyramid Lake). Higher gusts of 80 to 90 mph were noted in the Virginia Range and southwest of Gardnerville, with gusts over 100 mph at the Galena RAWS. Numerous roof and fences were damaged and several 4 foot diameter trees were downed on power lines in Gardnerville. Longtime residents of the area said this was the worst windstorm they had experienced in over 10 years. As many as 21,000 were without power around the area, with the worst damage to power lines in Douglas County. Finally, the high winds were blamed for the loss of power to 2 emergency communications repeaters (Eagle Ridge and Como) critical to Lyon County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong front pushed into the West on the 6th, bringing widespread high winds along with areas of enhanced downslope winds to western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts of 58 and 64 mph were measured at the Bulls Eye and Little Valley RAWS, respectively. However, strong downslope winds on the lower slopes of the Carson Range brought wind gusts over 80 mph, with a gusts to 109 mph between 1350PST and 1450PST at the Galena RAWS.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong front pushed into the West on the 6th, bringing widespread high winds along with areas of enhanced downslope winds to western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts to 63 mph were measured in the Smith and Mason Valleys, with a gust to 86  mph near Sweetwater Summit. Alternate highway 95 east of Yerington was closed for a few hours due to several accidents, with high winds and very low visibility due to blowing dust reported by the Lyon County EM.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong front pushed into the West on the 6th, bringing widespread high winds along with areas of enhanced downslope winds to western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mount Rose Ski area (above 8500 ft) reported 19 to 24 inches of heavy, wet snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moist and relatively mild flow off the Pacific brought rain and high elevation snow to the Carson Range on the 6th and early on the 7th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten to 12 inches of snow fell at Mount Charleston and Mountain Springs; six to seven inches fell in and around Red Rock Canyon.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold storm system brought snow to lower elevations of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One and a half inches of snow fell in Summerlin. Snow was observed, but did not accumulate, as low as 2500 feet.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold storm system brought snow to lower elevations of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two inches of snow fell in Searchlight.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold storm system brought snow to lower elevations of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 1 and 2 feet of snow fell on the east side of Lake Tahoe and in the Carson Range, including 13 inches in Glenbrook, 16 inches at the Mount Rose Ski area and 24 inches for the Diamond Peak ski area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure over the Pacific Northwest on the 27th dropped south through California and Nevada on the 28th. This brought heavy snow to portions of far western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread snowfall of between 0.5 and 3 inches was noted around the Reno and Carson City area. However, higher amounts fell in the foothills west of Carson City (up to 8 inches) and from the north valleys of Reno (3 to 6 inches) north to the Palomino Valley and the Red Rock area (8 to 15 inches).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure over the Pacific Northwest on the 27th dropped south through California and Nevada on the 28th. This brought heavy snow to portions of far western Nevada.

CZ_NAME_STR: LINCOLN COUNTY EXCEPT THE SHEEP RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four inches of snow fell in Pioche, with lesser amounts in Caliente and Panaca. Three vehicle rollovers and two slide-offs were attributed to the weather. Seven people were injured (indirect).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak storm system dropped light snow in Lincoln County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fourteen inches of snow fell at the Las Vegas Ski and Snowboard Resort, and 11.8 inches at Mount Charleston. Highway 158 was closed for a time due to cars stuck in the snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold low pressure system brought snow to the higher elevations of southern Nevada, along with a brief funnel cloud.

CZ_NAME_STR: LINCOLN COUNTY EXCEPT THE SHEEP RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five inches of snow fell in Pioche.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold low pressure system brought snow to the higher elevations of southern Nevada, along with a brief funnel cloud.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wet roads contributed to one vehicle accident with one minor injury (indirect).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold low pressure system brought snow to the higher elevations of southern Nevada, along with a brief funnel cloud.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud was photographed near Spirit Mountain.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold low pressure system brought snow to the higher elevations of southern Nevada, along with a brief funnel cloud.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds blew part of the roof off an old barn at the Corn Creek Visitors Center.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southwest winds ahead of a cold front caused isolated damage over the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred 40 miles E of Beatty.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southwest winds ahead of a cold front caused isolated damage over the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many SNOTEL sites reported between 8 and 20 inches of new snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system dumped heavy snow over the mountains of northern Elko county and the Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range. Many SNOTEL sites reported between 8 and 20 inches of new snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many SNOTEL sites reported between 9 and 16 inches of new snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system dumped heavy snow over the mountains of northern Elko county and the Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range. Many SNOTEL sites reported between 8 and 20 inches of new snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds ahead of a strong cold front gusted up to 70 mph. The strong winds damaged a patio awning at the Hotel Nevada in Ely. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front produced wind gusts up to 70 mph across portions of northern and central Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak wind gust was 60 mph (52 knots) 44 miles ENE of Beatty. Visibility was down to a quarter mile or less in Coaldale Junction, Dyer, Silver Peak, and Beatty. Two big rigs were blown over on Highway 95.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds and dust storm conditions to portions of southern Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts up to 67 mph were reported in Ruby and Clover Valleys on the lee side of the Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front produced wind gusts up to 70 mph across portions of northern and central Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts of 60 mph were reported in Tonopah.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front produced wind gusts up to 70 mph across portions of northern and central Nevada.

CZ_NAME_STR: LINCOLN COUNTY EXCEPT THE SHEEP RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility was down to 100 yards in Rachel.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds and dust storm conditions to portions of southern Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 69 mph was reported in West Wendover and a gust to 60 mph at the Spring Gulch RAWS site. The strong winds caused the driver of a semi to lose control of his vehicle causing the semi to travel off the south edge of Interstate 80 through the desert and eventually overturning on West Wendover Boulevard. The driver was injured and transported to the hospital.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front produced wind gusts up to 70 mph across portions of northern and central Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak wind occurred at Indian Springs (KINS). Visibility was briefly down to one quarter mile in Amargosa Valley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds and dust storm conditions to portions of southern Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak gust occurred at McCarran Airport (KLAS). Visibility was down to one mile in blowing dust. At least five light poles and seven large trees blew down. One tree fell onto power lines, one fell onto a car, and another knocked down a concrete block wall. About 2500 customers lost power.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds and dust storm conditions to portions of southern Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail up to 3/4 inch in diameter covered the ground a couple of inches deep.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong thunderstorm produced quarter size hail just east of Wells near Moor summit along Interstate 80. The hail covered the ground a couple of inches deep.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved through the Tonopah area producing a wind gust to 59 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved through Tonopah producing wind gusts up to 59 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility was down to a quarter mile in Amargosa Valley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent spring storm system brought strong winds and thunderstorms to much of the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds snapped a large tree, blew out windows at the Pahrump Nugget casino, and knocked down a satellite dish at KPVM-TV. The storm also produced half inch hail.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent spring storm system brought strong winds and thunderstorms to much of the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain left standing water at the intersection of Mountain Vista Road and Harmon Avenue.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent spring storm system brought strong winds and thunderstorms to much of the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A dust devil lifted a 798 pound, 5000 gallon water tank, carried it over a structure, and dropped it into a mesquite tree about 270 feet north, destroying both the tank and the tree.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dust devil near Moapa caused damage.
An unseasonable low pressure system moving overhead helped trigger scattered thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert. Two of the storms produced large hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail fell for 15 minutes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonable low pressure system moving overhead helped trigger scattered thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert. Two of the storms produced large hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to penny size hail covered the highway to a  depth of 2 inches. One vehicle slide off  was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced penny size hail that covered the highway to a depth of 2 inches.|One vehicle slide off was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding washed out sections of Echo Canyon Dam Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonable upper low east of the area helped fuel showers and thunderstorms over the southern Great Basin and Mojave Desert. Isolated flash flooding occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rocks and mud washed over Highway 266 11 miles W of Lida.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonable upper low east of the area helped fuel showers and thunderstorms over the southern Great Basin and Mojave Desert. Isolated flash flooding occurred.
Hail up to the size of dimes was reported in Ely.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A dust devil tore carport awnings off two mobile homes in the Riviera Mobile Home Park.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dust devil caused damage in east Las Vegas.
Dry microburst winds gusts up to 71 mph were reported across portions of northeast Nevada.
Dry microburst winds gusts up to 71 mph were reported across portions of northeast Nevada.
Dry microburst winds gusts up to 71 mph were reported across portions of northeast Nevada.
Dry microburst winds gusts up to 71 mph were reported across portions of northeast Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A video shows an estimated quarter to half dollar size hail falling on Interstate 80 near Pequop summit.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A video shows quarter to half dollar size hail falling on Pequop Summit.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail covered the ground and took off  leaves and twigs. Hail was mostly pea to dime size, with some hailstones near nickel size.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hail up to the size of nickles fell in Spring Creek and took off leaves and twigs from trees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Nevada Division of Emergency Management reported golf-ball sized hail.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure centered over southern California extended north into western Nevada on the 5th.  Relatively moist and unstable conditions brought thunderstorm development in the afternoon. Most thunderstorms were relatively weak, although several thunderstorms over Mineral County were much stronger than the average.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The storm survey was supplemented by a public video of the tornado moving along 5th street in Hawthorne. The tornado was determined to be EF-1 for 0.3 miles on the east side of Hawthorne (near 5th street) and EF-0 elsewhere. Approximately 10 to 15 homes and businesses were severely damaged along with power lines and road signs. One 2 foot diameter tree was blown over onto a mobile home and 2 vehicles were severely damaged. This tornado was associated with a non-supercell thunderstorm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure centered over southern California extended north into western Nevada on the 5th.  Relatively moist and unstable conditions brought thunderstorm development in the afternoon. Most thunderstorms were relatively weak, although several thunderstorms over Mineral County were much stronger than the average.

Low pressure centered over southern California extended north into western Nevada on the 5th.  Relatively moist and unstable conditions brought thunderstorm development in the afternoon. Most thunderstorms were relatively weak, although several thunderstorms over Mineral County were much stronger than the average.
An unseasonable upper level low combined with moisture from the remnants of a tropical cyclone to generate isolated thunderstorms over the southern Great Basin. One storm produced hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Per a spotter report, 1.13 inches of rain fell in about an hour in the Six Mile Canyon area near the Lyon and Storey County line. Lyon County Emergency Management  received reports of significant yard and landscaping damage as well as water in garages. Also, heavy equipment was required to remove mud from streets in the Mark Twain community as well as in Six Mile Canyon (Storey County).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving thunderstorms with heavy rainfall produced flash flooding near dry washes leading out of the Virginia Range on the 9th and the Pine Nut Mountains  on the 10th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water and mud covered Echo Dam Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually late-season low pressure system combined with unusually early-season deep subtropical moisture to fuel scattered thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin. Some storms produced flash flooding, and isolated wind damage also occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Douglas County Emergency Manager reported 9 homes with damage due to flooding near the low water crossings in the Ruhenstroth subdivision area. A fire chief noted that the completely dry Pine Nut Creek was rapidly filled with a 4 to 5 foot wall of water.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving thunderstorms with heavy rainfall produced flash flooding near dry washes leading out of the Virginia Range on the 9th and the Pine Nut Mountains  on the 10th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Douglas County Emergency Manager reported flash flooding impacts near low water crossings along Sawmill and Arroyo Roads.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving thunderstorms with heavy rainfall produced flash flooding near dry washes leading out of the Virginia Range on the 9th and the Pine Nut Mountains  on the 10th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Eureka county heriffs department reported flooding and mud on State Route 306 between mile marker 16 and Interstate 80, and flooding on State Route 278 between mile marker 61  and 74. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding washed mud and debris across several highways in northern Lander and northern Eureka counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lander county Sheriff Department reported flooding on State Route 305 between mile post 82 and mile post 108. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding washed mud and debris across several highways in northern Lander and northern Eureka counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water and mud were over Highway 264 in three places between mile markers 3 and 9.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually late-season low pressure system combined with unusually early-season deep subtropical moisture to fuel scattered thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin. Some storms produced flash flooding, and isolated wind damage also occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small, high based (likely above 12,000 ft AGL) thunderstorm produced the severe gust. The gust was recorded at a Nevada DOT site.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small thunderstorm dropped a severe outflow gust on highway 50 between Stagecoach and Silver Springs.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain in the Las Vegas Valley left several inches of standing water on some streets, knocked out power to over 1700 customers, and contributed to several vehicle accidents which resulted in seven injuries (indirect).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually late-season low pressure system combined with unusually early-season deep subtropical moisture to fuel scattered thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin. Some storms produced flash flooding, and isolated wind damage also occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds blew out a 7-11 sign at Nellis and Stewart.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually late-season low pressure system combined with unusually early-season deep subtropical moisture to fuel scattered thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin. Some storms produced flash flooding, and isolated wind damage also occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning set fire to a palm tree near Nellis and Sahara.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually late-season low pressure system combined with unusually early-season deep subtropical moisture to fuel scattered thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin. Some storms produced flash flooding, and isolated wind damage also occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures in Las Vegas reached Excessive Heat Warning levels on five days during the 12-day period, and were just below criteria for the remainder of the period. McCarran Airport had never before recorded a low of 90 degrees or higher in June; three such days occurred during this period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures in Las Vegas reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria on five non-consecutive days between June 19th through June 30th, and were just below criteria for the remainder of the period. One direct fatality and one indirect fatality in June were attributed to the heat, (several more people died during the first four days of July), and at least 17 people required medical treatment for heat related illnesses or dehydration. Paramedics responded to numerous other calls.
Thunderstorms brought severe outflow winds on the 27th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds snapped off the top part of a tree. It was estimated from pictures that the tree was 3 to 4 inches in diameter where it snapped.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds snapped off the top of a tree in Spring Creek.  Thunderstorm winds up to 63 mph were also reported across other parts of Elko county.
Thunderstorm winds snapped off the top of a tree in Spring Creek.  Thunderstorm winds up to 63 mph were also reported across other parts of Elko county.
Thunderstorm winds snapped off the top of a tree in Spring Creek.  Thunderstorm winds up to 63 mph were also reported across other parts of Elko county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports were received of dime to nickel size hail.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced dime to nickle size hail in Jackpot.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving thunderstorms with torrential rainfall in the higher terrain overwhelmed city drainage systems, causing flash flooding in East Sparks. Some areas were under several feet of water, with standing water and debris making travel difficult along Sparks and Vista Blvds. According to Sparks Police at least a dozen cars were stuck in the flooding. Water damage to Whitehead and Moss Elementary Schools was estimated at between 400K and 450K.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving thunderstorms with heavy to torrential rainfall affected western Nevada on the 30th. Compared to Reno sounding climatology since 1994, atmospheric moisture was near maximum values for late June.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured at the NWS office.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving thunderstorms with heavy to torrential rainfall affected western Nevada on the 30th. Compared to Reno sounding climatology since 1994, atmospheric moisture was near maximum values for late June.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thirteen people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes (11 direct, two indirect) during the first four days of July.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures finally fell below Excessive Heat Warning levels on July 1st; however, 13 people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes during the first four days of the month.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A gust of 73 mph was measured 5 miles WNW of Laughlin, and a gust of 100 mph was measured at the mid-span of the Hoover Dam Bypass Bridge.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoon moisture fueled thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin. Several storms produced severe weather and flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lyon County Emergency Management reported that highway 342 through Silver City was flooded with water, gravel and debris. Traffic was diverted to an alternate truck route. The time of the flooding is estimated based on radar.

Damages are approximate and based on the dividing of Douglas County Emergency Management's damage estimates for both July 8 and 9.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistent moderate to high atmospheric moisture combined with daytime heating to produce thunderstorms (many with heavy rainfall) early in the month. Periods of slow-moving thunderstorms combined with the heavy rain to bring flash flooding to western Nevada. One of the top flash flooding events in the past 25 years affected Douglas County (Johnson Lane area) on the 8th and 9th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire at the Clark County Wetlands Park destroyed a wooden footbridge.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonable upper level low moving in from the Pacific helped trigger thunderstorms over eastern California and adjacent areas of western Nevada. Isolated severe weather and flash flooding occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A dust devil tore down two awnings at a mobile home park.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures and mostly clear skies spawned a dust devil in Las Vegas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roughly ten power poles were snapped along Lee Renfro Road due to strong thunderstorm winds. Time is estimated based off radar and received reports.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One to 4 inches of snow was reported between the 2nd and 3rd above the lower valley floors. A medical condition (primary cause per investigators) combined with the snow and cold to cause severe hypothermia in an elderly man. He went out for a walk the afternoon of the 2nd and was not found until late morning on the 3rd. He was alive but later died at the hospital. The victim was found at around 6,200 feet in the Brunswick Canyon area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A light snowfall (1 to 4 inches above 4800-5000 ft) fell on the 2nd and 3rd. The snow and cold contributed to a man's death in the Pine Nut Mountains on the 3rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 60 mph was recorded at the Ely ASOS. The high winds snapped a large tree at its base in McGill.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early season winter storm brought heavy snow to portions of central and northern Nevada. Many valley areas in Eureka, Lander, and Elko counties received 6 to 10 inches of snow, with a few areas picking up between 1 and 2 feet. With leaves still on many trees due to a very warm October, the heavy wet snow broke many tree limbs that fell into power lines causing power outages. The hardest hit area was the town of Carlin where most residents were without power for much of the day. In addition strong winds ahead of the strong cold front gusted to 60 mph at Ely and snapped a large tree in McGill.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many valley locations received between 6 and 12 inches of new snow. Austin reported the most snow at 12 inches with Eureka and Beowawe coming in between 6 and 7 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early season winter storm brought heavy snow to portions of central and northern Nevada. Many valley areas in Eureka, Lander, and Elko counties received 6 to 10 inches of snow, with a few areas picking up between 1 and 2 feet. With leaves still on many trees due to a very warm October, the heavy wet snow broke many tree limbs that fell into power lines causing power outages. The hardest hit area was the town of Carlin where most residents were without power for much of the day. In addition strong winds ahead of the strong cold front gusted to 60 mph at Ely and snapped a large tree in McGill.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight to twelve inches of snow was reported in some areas. Emigrant pass reported 12 inches and 8 inches was reported near Beowawe. Many vehicle slide offs were reported with a few reporting property damage and 1 injury. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early season winter storm brought heavy snow to portions of central and northern Nevada. Many valley areas in Eureka, Lander, and Elko counties received 6 to 10 inches of snow, with a few areas picking up between 1 and 2 feet. With leaves still on many trees due to a very warm October, the heavy wet snow broke many tree limbs that fell into power lines causing power outages. The hardest hit area was the town of Carlin where most residents were without power for much of the day. In addition strong winds ahead of the strong cold front gusted to 60 mph at Ely and snapped a large tree in McGill.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts ranged from 8 to 23 inches in the valleys. Wild Horse Reservoir had a whopping 23 inches, closely followed by Tuscarora with 19 inches. Gibbs Ranch had 9 inches and Charleston 8 inches. Many SNOTEL sites had between 1 and 2 feet of snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early season winter storm brought heavy snow to portions of central and northern Nevada. Many valley areas in Eureka, Lander, and Elko counties received 6 to 10 inches of snow, with a few areas picking up between 1 and 2 feet. With leaves still on many trees due to a very warm October, the heavy wet snow broke many tree limbs that fell into power lines causing power outages. The hardest hit area was the town of Carlin where most residents were without power for much of the day. In addition strong winds ahead of the strong cold front gusted to 60 mph at Ely and snapped a large tree in McGill.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to ten inches of heavy wet snow broke many tree limbs which in turn brought down power lines causing power outages. The hardest hit area was the town of Carlin where most residents were without power for most of the day. Some power outages were reported in Elko and in Ruby Valley. The falling tree limbs also damaged some homes, vehicles, and fences. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early season winter storm brought heavy snow to portions of central and northern Nevada. Many valley areas in Eureka, Lander, and Elko counties received 6 to 10 inches of snow, with a few areas picking up between 1 and 2 feet. With leaves still on many trees due to a very warm October, the heavy wet snow broke many tree limbs that fell into power lines causing power outages. The hardest hit area was the town of Carlin where most residents were without power for much of the day. In addition strong winds ahead of the strong cold front gusted to 60 mph at Ely and snapped a large tree in McGill.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 8 and 19 inches of snow was reported by SNOTEL sites, with the highest total of 19 inches recorded at the Green Mountain SNOTEL.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early season winter storm brought heavy snow to portions of central and northern Nevada. Many valley areas in Eureka, Lander, and Elko counties received 6 to 10 inches of snow, with a few areas picking up between 1 and 2 feet. With leaves still on many trees due to a very warm October, the heavy wet snow broke many tree limbs that fell into power lines causing power outages. The hardest hit area was the town of Carlin where most residents were without power for much of the day. In addition strong winds ahead of the strong cold front gusted to 60 mph at Ely and snapped a large tree in McGill.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three inches of heavy, wet snow fell in Panaca. Several power poles, power lines, and tree limbs were knocked down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong trough of low pressure brought strong winds to southeast California and southern Nevada, along with snow in the higher elevations of the southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many locations across White Pine county received 8 to 13 inches of snow. Amounts include: 13 inches at Ely, 12 inches at Ruth, 11 inches at McGill. Mountain SNOTEL's received 8 to 13 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system dumped 8 to 13 inches of snow across many areas of White Pine county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread snow totals of 5 to 10 inches were noted in the Reno-Sparks area, highest on the north and west side of Reno (in lake effect band from Lake Tahoe). From the north valleys of Reno to Palomino Valley and Red Rock Rd near the California border lake effect snow from Pyramid Lake boosted snowfall totals to 8 to 15 inches, with the highest amounts in the Antelope and Hungry Valleys. Numerous broken tree branches were noted due to the heavy, wet snow and over 35,000 customers were without power in Washoe County due to downed power lines (morning of 11/10).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved over northeast California and western Nevada on the 9th and 10th, causing a modest snowfall. However, lake effect snow downwind of Lake Tahoe and Pyramid Lake greatly boosted snowfall totals for portions of western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred 40 miles E of Beatty.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another Pacific storm system brought strong winds to the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many SNOTEL sites received between 8 and 15 inches of snow with a report from the public in Conrad Creek at an elevation of 9200 feet of 22 inches of new snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of heavy snow set up across portions of southwestern Elko county. Six to ten inches of snow fell in Spring Creek while many SNOTEL sites in the Ruby Mountains received between 8 and 15 inches with one report of 22 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 6 and 10 inches of snow was reported in Spring Creek with the higher amounts closest to the Ruby Mountains.
