EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted to between 58 and 68 mph with some sustained winds over 40 mph from Reno south to Washoe Valley. Winds caused a semi to be blown over on southbound McCarran Blvd in Sparks, with the road closed for a time between Prater and Victorian. Also, a power pole was knocked down in Sparks. In Reno/Stead, a fence was blown down into a window with one of the fence's 4X4 posts snapped.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds brought some damage to the Reno-Sparks area on the 3rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 7 and 13 inches of snow fell in the Carson Range on the 10th and 11th, including 9 inches in Glenbrook, 7 to 10 inches in Incline Village and 13 inches at the Mount Rose Ski Area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold low pressure from the North Pacific brought heavy snow to the northern Sierra on the 10th and 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds toppled a power pole near Third and Court Streets in Elko. A wind gust to 59 mph was recorded at the National Weather Service Office and also at the Coal Mine Canyon CWOP site 6 miles northeast of Ryndon. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds gusting up to 59 mph toppled a power pole near Third and Court Streets in Elko.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds blew down several tree limbs 5 miles SSE of Summerlin. Blowing dust also reduced visibility.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of fast-moving cold fronts brought intermittent strong winds to the Mojave Desert for several days. Minor damage occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts between 58 and 67 mph were recorded on the north and northwest parts of Reno and in the Virginia Range on the morning of the 13th. Damage to a fence was reported in Reno-Stead.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure dropped from the northeast Pacific into Nevada on the 13th, bringing high winds to the western Great Basin along with heavy snow in the Carson Range.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fourteen to 20 inches of snow fell in the northern portion of the Carson Range, with 8 to 11 inches farther south in the Carson Range. At lake level, 5 inches of snow fell in Glenbrook.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure dropped from the northeast Pacific into Nevada on the 13th, bringing high winds to the western Great Basin along with heavy snow in the Carson Range.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds of 40-50 mph with gusts 60-70 mph were noted at several locations, including the Fallon Naval Air Station, along Interstate 80 near Lovelock (Toulon NDOT), and along highway 50 in the Silver Springs and Stagecoach areas.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure dropped from the northeast Pacific into Nevada on the 13th, bringing high winds to the western Great Basin along with heavy snow in the Carson Range.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many SNOTEL sites reported 1 to 2 feet of new snow. Reports from Jarbidge indicated around 2 feet of snow fell, and Wild Horse Reservoir reported 11 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought heavy snow to northern Elko county and the Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range. One to two feet of snow was reported at many SNOTEL sites. Wild Horse Reservoir reported 11 inches of snow while Jarbidge reported 26 inches of new snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One to nearly three feet of new snow was reported by SNOTEL sites.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One to two feet of snow fell above 7000 feet, including 18 inches at Daggett Pass. Up to 8 inches of snow fell down to around 6700 feet, with mainly rain below that level around Lake Tahoe.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moist but relatively warm west to east flow across the Pacific brought heavy high elevation snow to the Carson Range along with strong winds in the immediate lee of the Sierra.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts of 60 to 65 mph were recorded along I-580 and highway 395 in the north valleys of Reno and in the Washoe and Carson Valleys. Winds were sustained over 40 mph for a time as well. Wind prone areas along I-580 south of Reno reported wind gusts between 73 and 88 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moist but relatively warm west to east flow across the Pacific brought heavy high elevation snow to the Carson Range along with strong winds in the immediate lee of the Sierra.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several days of precipitation in the Carson Range of the northern Sierra due to moist flow from the Pacific wrapped up with a final heavy snowfall event on the 24th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of three Pacific storms impacted the desert Southwest, bringing periods of heavy rain, heavy snow, and locally dense fog.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports indicated 7 to 16 inches of snow fell across White Pine county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought 7 to 16 inches of snow to White Pine county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two dead trees were blown down overnight along Mary Jane Falls Trail west of Mount Charleston. The nearest sensor reported 15 mph wind gusts; based on terrain differences, the winds on the trail were estimated to be 30 mph. The time of occurrence was also estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two dead trees were blown down in the Spring Mountains by relatively weak winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One person died of hypothermia in Las Vegas. It was the sixth consecutive day of below normal temperatures.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One person died of hypothermia in Las Vegas. It was the sixth consecutive day of below normal temperatures.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The area in and near Virginia City reported between 9 and 12 inches of snow. Lesser amounts of 1 to 4 inches were noted in the Reno area down to 4800 to 5000 feet. Little or no snow (mainly rain) fell on the valley floors.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Fast-moving low pressure moved through northern Nevada on the 15th, bringing heavy snow to the higher elevations of the Virginia Range.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports indicated 6 to 12 inches of snow fell across much of southern Eureka county, including 6 to 9 inches in and around Eureka.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought 6 to 12 inches of snow to much of southern Eureka county.

Freezing rain along the Humboldt River valley from Beowawe to Ryndon caused over 100 vehicle accidents.  Lamoille Summit was closed for over an hour due to the icy conditions. Interstate 80 between Elko and Dunphy was also closed due to icy conditions and numerous accidents. Ice accumulation was around 0.15 inch in Elko.

Freezing rain along the Humboldt River valley from Beowawe to Ryndon caused over 100 vehicle accidents.  Lamoille Summit was closed for over an hour due to the icy conditions. Interstate 80 between Elko and Dunphy was also closed due to icy conditions and numerous accidents. Ice accumulation was around 0.15 inch in Elko.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds between 40-50 mph with gusts between 60 and 70 mph were recorded in the foothills north and northwest of Reno and in the Carson Valley, including along highway 395 and Interstate 580. In the wind-prone areas in and near Washoe Valley wind gusts reached as high as 90 mph. Damages from the high winds include: an uprooted 2-ft diameter tree in Carson City, 6 snapped power poles on Mount Rose highway, and fence damage near Cold Springs.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through western Nevada very early on the 30th, with high winds for portions of the area ahead of the front on the 29th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downslope winds off the Pine Nut Range brought sustained winds of 35-50 mph with gusts up to 75 mph to the Smith Valley.  Highway 95 near Hawthorne experienced wind gusts up to 68 mph  (Walker Lake NDOT) during the evening of the 29th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through western Nevada very early on the 30th, with high winds for portions of the area ahead of the front on the 29th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to eight inches of snow was reported in the Battle Mountain area and 7 inches 49 miles south of Beowawe. The Lewis Mountain SNOTEL reported 8 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across southwestern Elko county and northern Lander and northern Eureka counties. Six to seven inches was reported at many valley locations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to seven inches of snow was reported in Carlin, Elko, Ryndon, and Spring Creek.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across southwestern Elko county and northern Lander and northern Eureka counties. Six to seven inches was reported at many valley locations.

CZ_NAME_STR: LINCOLN COUNTY EXCEPT THE SHEEP RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell in Lincoln County, with 14 inches estimated in Pioche, 10 inches estimated in Caliente, and nine inches measured in Rachel. The event continued into (and reached warning criteria during) February.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific storm system brought high winds to the Owens Valley and Mojave Desert, high winds and severe thunderstorms to the Mojave Desert, and heavy snow to the southern Great Basin. The episode continued into February.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A station located 3.4 miles south-southwest of Yerington reported a storm total snowfall of 9.5 inches. In addition to snow, widespread winds of 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 35 mph caused blowing and drifting snow, with visibilities in Hawthorne and Yerington often below 3 miles, and sometimes briefly down to between 1/2 and 3/4 of a mile.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from off the Oregon coast through southern Nevada between the morning of the 31st and the 1st of February. The development of a strong surface low over southern Nevada brought periods of low visibility in blowing snow to parts of the Basin and Range.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A station 2.6 miles west-northwest of Fernley received a storm total of 11 inches of snow. This was enhanced substantially by lake-effect snow off of Pyramid Lake during the afternoon and evening of the 31st. In addition to snow, ASOS and AWOS observations from the Lovelock, Silver Springs and Fallon airfields indicated sustained winds in the 15 to 25 mph range, with gusts 30 to 40 mph in the afternoon and evening of the 31st. This caused blowing snow with visibilities generally between 1 and 3 miles, but occasionally below 1 mile.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from off the Oregon coast through southern Nevada between the morning of the 31st and the 1st of February. The development of a strong surface low over southern Nevada brought periods of low visibility in blowing snow to parts of the Basin and Range.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread snow totals of 4 to 8 inches were reported around the Reno-Sparks area, with lesser amounts between 2 and 5 inches farther south. Areas in and near the foothills west of Reno received between 8 and 10 inches of snowfall. Heavy, lake-effect snow off of Pyramid Lake caused whiteout conditions near Wadsworth, with two jackknifed big rigs causing the closure of westbound Interstate 80 in the evening.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from off the Oregon coast through southern Nevada between the morning of the 31st and the 1st of February. The development of a strong surface low over southern Nevada brought periods of low visibility in blowing snow to parts of the Basin and Range.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Tonopah and the Big Smoky Valley reported 11 inches of snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm dumped 6 to 12 inches of snow in many valley locations and up to 18 inches in the mountains. In addition winds gusting over 40 mph in White Pine county caused drifting of snow up to 4 feet deep making travel nearly impossible. Schools and county offices were closed the next day.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Reno-Tahoe International airport recorded sustained winds over 40 mph for at least an hour during the afternoon of the 17th, with a gust to 58 mph at 1423PST. The NDOT sensor along Highway 395 in the Cold Springs Valley noted sustained winds as high as 47 mph. In the foothills south and southwest of Reno (including I-580) and in the Virginia Range, wind gusts 60-66 mph were recorded. The winds uprooted several trees and damaged a large sculpture in the Reno-Sparks area, and caused a transformer in Virginia City to blow out with a several-hour power outage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent cold front brought strong, damaging winds along with heavy snowfall to portions of far western Nevada and the northern Sierra/Carson Range.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred 2 miles N of Amargosa Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds blew down a 50 by 25 foot sign at the Double Dice RV Park in Elko. Wind gusts up to 51 mph were measured at the NWS office about 1/4 mile away. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds to portions of southern Elko county. The Pilot Peak mesonet site along Interstate 80 recorded a peak wind gust of 66 mph. A mesonet site near West Wendover recorded a gust to 60 mph. Strong winds also blew down a large sign at the Double Dice RV Park in Elko.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent cold front brought strong, damaging winds along with heavy snowfall to portions of far western Nevada and the northern Sierra/Carson Range.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds of 40 and 55 mph with gusts 60 to 80 mph were recorded in and just east of the foothills of the Carson Range south of Reno on the 13th. More isolated high winds were noted at the Reno-Stead airport (sustained 40 with gusts to 58) and the UNR Agricultural Farm (gust to 64 mph). The high winds caused a big rig to overturn on highway 395 near Stead. Finally, severe turbulence aloft near the Reno-Tahoe airport caused delays and cancellations on the morning of the 13th.

Snowfall rates were heavy with most of the snow falling within 3 to 6 hours. The heavy, wet snow caused a tree to topple onto a car in Sparks.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water 1-1.5 feet deep flowed into a house near W. Lake Mead Blvd. and N. Tonopah Dr. A patio awning in North Las Vegas collapsed under the weight of heavy rain. Water 6-12 inches deep flowed over several streets around the valley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Precipitable water at or near all-time April records and an unseasonably strong, cold Pacific storm system came together to produce a very unusual April flash flooding episode.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms approximately 15 to 30 miles west of Fallon produced outflow winds as high as 49 mph gusting to 60 mph at the Naval Air Station in Fallon. Visibility was reduced to between 1 and 2 miles as the wind kicked up large amounts of dust.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of heavy fuels and gusty winds caused the Tule Fire to run down the slopes of the Virginia Mountains in the Hardscrabble Canyon area on the 29th. The fire burned 10 structures (including 4 unoccupied homes) and 2 vehicles and forced the evacuation of about 600 persons in Sutcliffe. The fire also knocked out power in the town for several days. A declaration of disaster was made for the reservation and Pyramid Lake was closed for recreation until August 5th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Virginia Mountains Fire Complex started on the 28th due to lightning. By the end of the month it had burned over 40,000 acres. The largest fire in the complex was the Tule Fire (around 27,000 acres by month's end) which damaged property in Sutcliffe on the Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe's Reservation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Virginia Mountains Complex, which was started by lightning on July 28th, was fully contained on the 5th. The complex burned over 62,000 acres, with the largest fire in the complex being the Tule Fire which burned about 36,000 acres.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A prescribed burn that was thought to be mopped up on October 13th flared up as high winds affected the Carson Range early on the 14th. The Little Valley Fire burned through 2,291 acres and destroyed 23 homes and 17 outbuildings. According to a Reno Gazette Journal investigation, the estimated value of 18 of the homes exceeded 26 million dollars with an independent fire consultant indicating that damages could exceed 80 million. The Little Valley RAWS measured a wind gust of 87 mph around 130 AM PDT on the 14th, close to the time of the wildfire start.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two low pressure systems brought a combination of strong winds, significant rain, and high elevation snow on the 14th and 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds of 35 to 45 mph with gusts up to 74 mph were recorded early on the 14th, mainly for the North Valleys of Reno, the foothills of the Carson Range, and in Washoe Valley. These winds were responsible for the rapid spread of the Little Valley wildfire and for a number of delays and cancellations at the Reno-Tahoe International airport.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two low pressure systems brought a combination of strong winds, significant rain, and high elevation snow on the 14th and 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds over 40 mph with gusts 58 to 64 mph were recorded on the 19th along the Highway 395/Interstate 580 corridor, including at the Reno-Tahoe International Airport, in the Carson Valley, and for the Reno-Stead area. In the foothills south and southwest of Reno winds gusted between 65 and 75 mph, with gusts as high as 81 mph at the Galena RAWS.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front brought high winds to portions of far western Nevada on the 19th.

A winter storm brought heavy snow to the Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range and northern Elko county. SNOTEL sites reported between 8 and 16 inches of snow and a COOP observer at Wild Horse Reservoir reported 7 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts between 63 (Bulls Eye) and 89 (Galena) mph were recorded along Mount Rose Highway on the 15th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure and an associated cold front brought high winds to western Nevada on the 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gusts between 73 and 89 mph were recorded in and near the Carson Range southwest of Reno and west of Carson City and Minden, with gusts between 60 and 70 mph along Highway 395 in the north valleys of Reno.  A semi truck was blown over in Washoe Valley at around 530PST. At the Reno-Tahoe International airport, at least 11 flights were cancelled, with at least 5 diversions, due to winds and turbulence.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure and an associated cold front brought high winds to western Nevada on the 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread wind gusts of 58 to 64 mph (64 mph at Walker Lake NDOT) were noted on the morning of the 15th, with sustained winds around 40 mph at times in the Smith Valley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure and an associated cold front brought high winds to western Nevada on the 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak gust was measured 2 miles NW of Centennial Hills. Around the valley, a traffic light pole fell onto a car, injuring the driver; a mobile billboard truck and parked semi trailer were blown over; and Interstate 215 was closed for several hours due to construction materials being blown from a flyover ramp under construction into the traffic lanes below.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific storm system brought high winds to portions of the Mojave Desert and snow to the southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak gust was measured at the Mercury-Desert Rock (KDRA) ASOS.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific storm system brought high winds to portions of the Mojave Desert and snow to the southern Great Basin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred 3 miles ENE of Mount Charleston.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow caused reduced visibility and slick areas on Highway 93 north of Pioche, leading to multiple crashes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wild Horse Reservoir reported 8 inches of new snow. Many SNOTEL sites reported between 8 and 15 inches of new snow.

A winter storm brought heavy snow to northern Lander and northern Eureka counties and the Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range. Battle Mountain and Beowawe reported 6 inches of snow. SNOTEL sites in the Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range reported between 9 and 12 inches of snow.

A winter storm brought heavy snow to northern Lander and northern Eureka counties and the Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range. Battle Mountain and Beowawe reported 6 inches of snow. SNOTEL sites in the Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range reported between 9 and 12 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 12 inches of snow fell at the Sheldon SNOTEL, with higher amounts possible farther west closer to the Surprise Valley in eastern California.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved slowly south near the Pacific Northwest coast between the 2nd and the 4th before moving inland over northern California and Nevada on the 5th. The system brought significant snow and rain to the northern Sierra and western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall between 43 and 70 inches was reported in the higher elevations (generally above about 7000 feet) of the Carson Range, with between 9 and 14 inches at lake level, between the 2nd and the 5th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved slowly south near the Pacific Northwest coast between the 2nd and the 4th before moving inland over northern California and Nevada on the 5th. The system brought significant snow and rain to the northern Sierra and western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two people died in Las Vegas of cold related causes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two people died in Las Vegas of Cold related causes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rain changed to snow on the afternoon of the 4th, with widespread snowfall totals of 4 to 6 inches in the Reno-Sparks area by the morning of the 5th. Areas farther north in the Palomino Valley and along Red Rock Road north of Stead received up to 8 inches. Lesser amounts between 1 and 4 inches fell south of the Reno-Sparks area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved slowly south near the Pacific Northwest coast between the 2nd and the 4th before moving inland over northern California and Nevada on the 5th. The system brought significant snow and rain to the northern Sierra and western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 3 and 6 inches of snow fell in the Fallon area from the evening of the 4th into the morning of the 5th. Higher amounts between 6 and 9 inches fell between Sutcliffe and Fernley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved slowly south near the Pacific Northwest coast between the 2nd and the 4th before moving inland over northern California and Nevada on the 5th. The system brought significant snow and rain to the northern Sierra and western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain resulted in 0.1 inches of ice 3 miles west-southwest of Gardnerville.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong atmospheric river brought heavy rain with widespread flooding on the 8th and 9th. There was a period of snow on the 7th, as well as freezing rain in some lower valleys into the morning of the 8th.  Pre-emptive planning caused the closure of public schools and courts in Washoe County on the 9th. Many roads were closed due to flooding, overwhelmed and blocked culverts, and debris flows in the Reno-Sparks, Carson City, and Minden areas on the 8th. A damage estimate from Washoe County Emergency Management for the entire county in January was over $15M, with much of the damage between the 7th and 9th. In Storey County, a damage estimate from flooding and snow in January was $6M for public infrastructure.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 1300-1400 homes were evacuated in the Quilici area of South Reno due to flooding, likely from the overwhelming of Steamboat Ditch and nearby channels with the exceptionally heavy rainfall. The end timing of the flooding is roughly estimated. NOTE: No information is available regarding damage to homes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong atmospheric river brought heavy rain with widespread flooding on the 8th and 9th. There was a period of snow on the 7th, as well as freezing rain in some lower valleys into the morning of the 8th.  Pre-emptive planning caused the closure of public schools and courts in Washoe County on the 9th. Many roads were closed due to flooding, overwhelmed and blocked culverts, and debris flows in the Reno-Sparks, Carson City, and Minden areas on the 8th. In Storey County, a damage estimate from flooding and snow in January was $6M for public infrastructure.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twenty five structures, including at least 10 homes (one 8-plex and two single-family homes), were damaged by flood waters in Dayton by the morning of the 9th. Flooding of the two single family homes in East Dayton may have been largely due to breaks in ditches and culverts incapable of handling the exceptionally large volume of water. Water depth varied from 6 inches to as much as 3 feet on the south side of the Carson River. Standing flood waters lasted for at least several days after the initial flood surge on the 8th. Schools were closed county-wide on the 9th. The damage estimate from the Lyon County Emergency Manager is considered very low-end and could actually be several million dollars for Dayton alone.  In February, a Federal Disaster Declaration was approved for the January flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding from Steamboat Creek and the North Truckee Drain (near I-80 in Sparks) combined with some input from the Truckee River to bring a large area of lowland flooding between McCarran Blvd and Hidden Valley, as well as south of Interstate 80 in the Sparks Industrial area. Several days of notice allowed many businesses and homes in Hidden Valley (near Boynton Slough) to prepare flood mitigation measures including sandbagging. However, several homes in Hidden Valley still had flood damage due to overtopped sandbags and/or basement flooding.  The timing of the flood is approximate and the damage is roughly estimated.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway 446 was destroyed by flood waters in more than 10 places on the southwest side of Pyramid Lake. Some sections were left with nearly 50-foot deep ravines. The highway was not re-opened to the public until early March. Repair cost based on Nevada Department of Transportation estimates from Reno-Gazette Journal article in February.

High winds were observed across southeast Elko county. The Pilot Peak Junction mesonet site reported a wind gust to 66 mph and the Spring Gulch RAWS site reported a wind gust to 62 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 6 and 9 feet of snow fell between the 9th and 12th in the the higher elevation of the northern Carson Range, including the Mount Rose and Diamond Peak ski areas. Farther south, Daggett Pass reported 45 inches of snowfall. Near lake level on the east side of Lake Tahoe, snowfall amounts ranged from 20 to 32 inches. Numerous power outages were noted and Incline Village declared a snow emergency with roads not expected to be cleared for at least a couple days.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure over the northeast Pacific on the 9th moved southeast slowly, reaching northern California on the 12th. This brought exceptional snowfall and a period of blizzard conditions to the northern Sierra (Carson Range), as well as a period of snowfall in the lower elevations of western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Virginia City received a total of 26 inches of snowfall (in multiple precipitation waves). Lower elevations received much less snowfall with periods of rain and snow. Elevations below 5500 feet mainly received between 2 and 4 inches of snowfall, although higher amounts to between 5 and 6.5 inches were noted in Sparks and north of Interstate 80 above 5000 feet.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure over the northeast Pacific on the 9th moved southeast slowly, reaching northern California on the 12th. This brought exceptional snowfall and a period of blizzard conditions to the northern Sierra (Carson Range), as well as a period of snowfall in the lower elevations of western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nevada route 341 (Mount Rose Highway) was closed for blizzard conditions into the morning of the 11th. Wind gusts at a couple RAWS sites were gusting between 35 and 45 mph during the snowfall event.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure over the northeast Pacific on the 9th moved southeast slowly, reaching northern California on the 12th. This brought exceptional snowfall and a period of blizzard conditions to the northern Sierra (Carson Range), as well as a period of snowfall in the lower elevations of western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds were as high as 63 mph at the Walker Lake NDOT sensor. Gusts at that site were mostly between 70 and 85 mph, but reached 105 mph at 1800PST. Smith Valley and Yerington has automated sensors with gusts briefly between 58 and 63 mph. The winds caused at least two semi-trucks to blow over on Highway 95 near Walker Lake.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure over the northeast Pacific on the 9th moved southeast slowly, reaching northern California on the 12th. This brought exceptional snowfall and a period of blizzard conditions to the northern Sierra (Carson Range), as well as a period of snowfall in the lower elevations of western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak gust was measured 1 mile W of Summerlin. Around the valley, at least two trees were blown down, a large concrete sign began to lean but did not fall, and windblown debris got into a power substation and knocked out power to two Las Vegas Strip resorts for just over an hour.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Still another Pacific storm hot on the heels of the previous storm brought high winds to the Las Vegas Valley and heavy snow to the Spring Mountains.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many locations from Yerington to Fernley to Fallon received between 1 and 3 inches of snowfall. However, a few sites between Fernley and Fallon reported between 5 and 6 inches of snowfall, mainly between early morning and mid afternoon on the 12th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure over the northeast Pacific on the 9th moved southeast slowly, reaching northern California on the 12th. This brought exceptional snowfall and a period of blizzard conditions to the northern Sierra (Carson Range), as well as a period of snowfall in the lower elevations of western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several stations reported 13 to 17 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fifteen inches of snow fell in Lee Canyon.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several closely spaced storm systems passed through the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin, bringing widespread heavy snow to the higher terrain and isolated flooding problems to the lower elevations.

A winter storm brought heavy snow to portions of White Pine county. Ely picked up 8 inches of new snow while Ruth received 7 inches of new snow. SNOTEL sites in the mountains observed between 8 and 12 inches of new snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cooperative observers reported between 2 and 3 feet of snow on the east shore of Lake Tahoe and for the Daggett Pass area. The Mount Rose ski area reported more than 6 feet of snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure remained over the northeast Pacific from late on the 19th into the 23rd, with a couple disturbances moving over Nevada during the period. This brought another round of significant snowfall to the northern Sierra and portions of western Nevada.

In addition strong winds caused blowing and drifting of snow which resulted in the closure of highway 93 between Lages Junction to north of Wells as road crews could not keep up with the snow drifts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread snowfall totals of 4 to 8 inches were noted in valley locations through the evening of the 22nd, mainly near and west of Interstate 580/Highway 395, with lesser amounts of 2 to 4 inches farther east. Local amounts between 8 and 13 inches were reported in the foothills west and southwest of Reno. Finally, between the 20th and 23rd, Virginia City received almost 27 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Reno-Tahoe International airport recorded a gust to 73 mph at 1934PST on the 6th. Gusts 65 to 73 mph were noted in the foothills along Interstate 580 south of Reno and near the Stead airport.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of precipitation associated with an atmospheric river brought widespread rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches in far western Nevada, with much higher rainfall and/or liquid equivalent amounts between 3 and 6.5 inches in the foothills and Carson Range west of Interstate 580 and Highway 395. The higher elevations of the Carson Range received up to several feet of snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Residents of Paradise Valley were inundated on at least two separate occasions as water poured off the Santa Rosa Mountains through the various creeks surrounding the town. Humboldt county reported over 68 rural roads that were damaged by the flooding. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain on a much above normal snow pack combined with frozen ground caused extensive flooding across northern Nevada, especially across Elko county. The excessive runoff caused the Twenty One Mile dam north of Montello to fail sending flood waters 2-3 feet deep down Twenty One Mile Creek flooding buildings at the Gamble Ranch and washing out a section of State Route 233 and railroad tracks. Flooding also stopped trains traveling through northern Elko County as tracks were underwater. About 30 homes and a few businesses in both Montello and Wells were flooded along with some homes and outbuildings in rural areas. Many rural roads were damaged and had washouts. US highway 93 was closed both south and north of Wells for a time as flood waters submerged the road. Salmon Falls Creek overflowed US highway 93 and completely submerged the adjoining rest area. Extensive shoulder damage was reported along US Highway 93 mainly north of Wells. Humboldt county reported over 68 rural roads that were damaged by the flooding. Residents of Paradise Valley were inundated on at least two separate occasions as water poured off the Santa Rosa Mountains through the various creeks surrounding the town. All the runoff caused the Humboldt River to rise above flood stage. This caused extensive flooding of homes and businesses along and near the Humboldt River in Elko. Interstate 80 between Elko and Wells was reduced to one lane in places due to flood waters over the road. A total of 25 homes in Elko, Wells, and Montello were totally destroyed or suffered extensive damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rain on a much above normal snow pack combined with frozen ground caused extensive flooding. Extensive shoulder damage was reported along US Highway 93 mainly north of Wells. Humboldt county reported over 68 rural roads that were damaged by the flooding. Residents of Paradise Valley were inundated on at least two separate occasions as water poured off the Santa Rosa Mountains through the various creeks surrounding the town. All the runoff caused the Humboldt River to rise above flood stage. This caused extensive flooding of homes and businesses along and near the Humboldt River in Elko. Interstate 80 between Elko and Wells was reduced to one lane in places due to flood waters over the road. A total of 25 homes in Elko, Wells, and Montello were totally destroyed or suffered extensive damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve to 16 inches of water was running over Mt Rose Highway in the Tahoe Meadows area (near the highway summit) on the morning of the 8th. The highway was closed between Incline Village and the summit until the afternoon of the 9th due to the flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of precipitation associated with an atmospheric river brought widespread rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches in far western Nevada, with much higher rainfall and/or liquid equivalent amounts between 3 and 6.5 inches in the foothills and Carson Range west of Interstate 580 and Highway 395. The higher elevations of the Carson Range received up to several feet of snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rising waters behind Twenty One Mile Dam caused the dam to fail sending a 2 to 3 foot wall of water downstream. The flood waters washed out a section of State Route 233 and railroad tracks. The waters flooded buildings at the Gamble Ranch and washed out some county roads. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain on a much above normal snow pack combined with frozen ground caused extensive flooding across northern Nevada, especially across Elko county. The excessive runoff caused the Twenty One Mile dam north of Montello to fail sending flood waters 2-3 feet deep down Twenty One Mile Creek flooding buildings at the Gamble Ranch and washing out a section of State Route 233 and railroad tracks. Flooding also stopped trains traveling through northern Elko County as tracks were underwater. About 30 homes and a few businesses in both Montello and Wells were flooded along with some homes and outbuildings in rural areas. Many rural roads were damaged and had washouts. US highway 93 was closed both south and north of Wells for a time as flood waters submerged the road. Salmon Falls Creek overflowed US highway 93 and completely submerged the adjoining rest area. Extensive shoulder damage was reported along US Highway 93 mainly north of Wells. Humboldt county reported over 68 rural roads that were damaged by the flooding. Residents of Paradise Valley were inundated on at least two separate occasions as water poured off the Santa Rosa Mountains through the various creeks surrounding the town. All the runoff caused the Humboldt River to rise above flood stage. This caused extensive flooding of homes and businesses along and near the Humboldt River in Elko. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread gusts between 60 and 70 mph were recorded in the valleys on the 9th, with gusts 70 to as high as 92 mph (Browns Creek Bridge on I-580) in the foothills. Numerous downed trees and power lines were noted, with as many as 7,000 to 8,000 customers without power early in the afternoon, mostly in Douglas County. A big rig was blown over on Highway 395 near Stead. Finally, at least 7 flights into the Reno-Tahoe International airport were delayed or cancelled due to the winds.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of precipitation associated with an atmospheric river brought widespread rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches in far western Nevada, with much higher rainfall and/or liquid equivalent amounts between 3 and 6.5 inches in the foothills and Carson Range west of Interstate 580 and Highway 395. The higher elevations of the Carson Range received up to several feet of snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periodic sustained winds over 40 mph with gusts as high as 62 mph were reported in various locations from near Lovelock (Toulon NDOT site) south and west to near Lahontan Reservoir (Bango DRI site) and Fallon (Naval Air Station).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of precipitation associated with an atmospheric river brought widespread rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches in far western Nevada, with much higher rainfall and/or liquid equivalent amounts between 3 and 6.5 inches in the foothills and Carson Range west of Interstate 580 and Highway 395. The higher elevations of the Carson Range received up to several feet of snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds over Sweetwater Summit (NV Highway 338) were sustained between 45 and 62 mph with gusts up to 82 mph on the 9th. Elsewhere, Wellington recorded gusts up to 59 mph and the Walker Lake NDOT had brief periods of high winds with gusts as high as 76 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of precipitation associated with an atmospheric river brought widespread rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches in far western Nevada, with much higher rainfall and/or liquid equivalent amounts between 3 and 6.5 inches in the foothills and Carson Range west of Interstate 580 and Highway 395. The higher elevations of the Carson Range received up to several feet of snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: County officials noted that 13 homes were threatened by waters overflowing from Swan Lake and nearby ditches on the 10th. Flooding continued through May, with the worst threat in March as additional rainfall and snowmelt input from Peavine Peak exacerbated flooding. Significant flooding continued into April before mitigation efforts began to contain the flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of precipitation associated with an atmospheric river brought widespread rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches in far western Nevada, with much higher rainfall and/or liquid equivalent amounts between 3 and 6.5 inches in the foothills and Carson Range west of Interstate 580 and Highway 395. The higher elevations of the Carson Range received up to several feet of snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts in the foothills of far western Nevada and in the north valleys of Reno ranged from 60 to 75 mph on the 16th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front brought a period of high winds on the morning of the 16th, mainly in the foothills and higher valleys of far western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds between 40 and 50 mph with gusts 60 to 84 mph occurred over Sweetwater Summit and along Highway 95 near Walker Lake on the morning of the 16th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front brought a period of high winds on the morning of the 16th, mainly in the foothills and higher valleys of far western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twenty two inches of snow fell on Mount Charleston.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought heavy snow to the mountains of southern Nevada, and isolated heavy rain to the lower elevations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Red Rock Scenic Loop and the access roads to Bonnie Springs Ranch and Spring Mountain State Park were all closed due to flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought heavy snow to the mountains of southern Nevada, and isolated heavy rain to the lower elevations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 5 feet of snow fell at ski areas in the Carson Range, with 3 feet at Daggett Pass, between the 20th and 22nd. In Incline Village at 6700 feet, 40 inches of snow was noted by a spotter. Below 6500 feet, 12 to 22 inches of snowfall was reported by cooperative observers. Mount Rose Highway (NV 431) was closed due to a localized avalanche on the evening of the 20th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving low pressure moved from the eastern Pacific on the 20th into northern Nevada on the 22nd, bringing heavy snow to portions of far western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread snowfall totals of 5 to 10 inches were noted on the north and west sides of Reno, including Stead and Cold Springs Valley, with 16 inches in Virginia City. In the lower valleys around Reno-Sparks, 2 to 4 inches was reported including 3.7 inches at the Reno-Tahoe airport.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving low pressure moved from the eastern Pacific on the 20th into northern Nevada on the 22nd, bringing heavy snow to portions of far western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wild horse reservoir reported 7 inches of snow and Jackpot 6 inches. Many SNOTEL sites reported between 1 and 2 feet of snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought heavy snow to northern Elko county and the Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range. Some valley location reported 6 to 7 inches of snow while the mountains reported 1 to 2 feet of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many SNOTEL sites reported 1 to 2 feet of snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought heavy snow to northern Elko county and the Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range. Some valley location reported 6 to 7 inches of snow while the mountains reported 1 to 2 feet of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fifteen to 19 inches of snow fell in the Carson Range and near Lake Tahoe, generally near and south of Highway 50. To the northeast of Lake Tahoe, 23 to 28 inches of snow was reported between Incline Village and the Mount Rose Ski area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold low pressure dropped from the Gulf of Alaska on the 3rd into Nevada on the 5th, bringing heavy snow to the northern Sierra and far western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Isolated snowfall amounts between 17 and 19 inches fell above 5000 feet west of Carson City on the 5th, with around 12 inches in Virginia City. Four to six inches of snow fell on the north and west sides of Reno, as well as near Carson City and east of Highway 395 in the Minden-Johnson Lane area. Six to 8 inches of snow was reported in the north valleys of Reno. Lesser snowfall amounts up to 3 inches fell in Sparks and in southeast Reno.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold low pressure dropped from the Gulf of Alaska on the 3rd into Nevada on the 5th, bringing heavy snow to the northern Sierra and far western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred 40 miles E of Beatty.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system diving in from the northwest brought a period of high winds to much of southern Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds gusting to 66 mph snapped 8 power poles along State Route 140 and damaged 3 power poles in the Paradise Hills area. In Winnemucca a carport was destroyed by the strong winds. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought winds gusting up to 85 mph to portions of northern and central Nevada. These strong winds blew down power poles in Humboldt county and did some other minor property damage. In northern Nye county the winds blew down the historic Mitzpah Hotel and Casino sign in Tonopah. The cold front brought heavy snow to portions of White Pine county with 9 to 11 inches reported in some locations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 60 mph was recorded at the Currant Creek RAWS site.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought winds gusting up to 85 mph to portions of northern and central Nevada. These strong winds blew down power poles in Humboldt county and did some other minor property damage. In northern Nye county the winds blew down the historic Mitzpah Hotel and Casino sign in Tonopah. The cold front brought heavy snow to portions of White Pine county with 9 to 11 inches reported in some locations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 64 mph was recorded at the Tonopah airport. These strong winds blew down the historic Mitzpah Hotel and Casino sign in Tonopah and blew down a 12 inch diameter tree in front of the museum.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind gust was measured at Lovelock-Derby Field. Visibility was reduced to 1.25 miles due to blowing dust with the outflow winds. Another thunderstorm brought visibility as low as 1/4 mile between 1810PST and 1820PST (with gusts up to 53 mph).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures brought isolated, high-based thunderstorms with strong outflow winds and a very localized flash flood.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind gust was measured at Lovelock-Derby Field. The wind was generated by outflow from earlier thunderstorms.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind gust (from the south) was measured at the Minden-Tahoe airport.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures brought isolated, high-based thunderstorms with strong outflow winds and a very localized flash flood.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rainfall persisted for almost 2 hours in the hills east of Yerington (near the Lyon/Mineral County line). A deputy sheriff reported a large wall of water coming down from the hills (in a typically dry wash). A National Weather Service employee investigated the scene a week later and noticed high water marks as much as 2.5 feet above Prospect St, with water damage to landscaping for multiple properties. Appreciable sediment was noted on Bybee Ln, Almond Rd, and Prospect St, with damage to Bybee Ln. (unpaved road). Damage roughly estimated based on little or no known home damage (mainly landscaping, unpaved roads).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures brought isolated, high-based thunderstorms with strong outflow winds and a very localized flash flood.
Thunderstorm wind gusts caused tree damage on the south side of Elko and a gust to 59  mph at Deeth.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Truckee Fire burned around 99,000 acres to the north and northeast of Fernley (and north of Interstate 80) between the 3rd and 10th. Extreme fire growth in grass and brush lead to the voluntary evacuation of 10 to 12 homes on Duffy Road northeast of Fernley on the 3rd; however, no homes were destroyed or damaged as fire fighters set up successful protection lines. Interstate 80 was closed between the evening of the 3rd and early morning on the 4th. The cost to fight the fire was in excess of $600K.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of lightning and human/unknown causes brought 5 separate wildfires to western and west-central Nevada between the 4th and 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Earthstone Fire burned over 41,000 acres (mainly north of Interstate 80) as periods of extreme fire behavior allowed it to spread between the hills east of Sparks to several miles west of Wadsworth. Interstate 80 was closed, mainly between mile markers 22 and 43 from the evening of the 3rd into early morning on the 4th. The fire was suspected to be human-caused with no lightning or downed power lines in the area. The cost to fight the fire totaled at least $3.5M.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of lightning and human/unknown causes brought 5 separate wildfires to western and west-central Nevada between the 4th and 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Winnemucca Ranch Fire east of Pyramid Highway and in Palomino Valley burned around 4800 acres. Although 58 structures were threatened at the onset of the fire, the fire only wound up destroying one mobile home and two outbuildings on Amy Road. The fire was human-caused.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of lightning and human/unknown causes brought 5 separate wildfires to western and west-central Nevada between the 4th and 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive heat criteria were reached in Las Vegas from the 6th through the 8th. From the 6th through the 10th, 20 people died of heat related causes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The season's first push of monsoon moisture brought scattered thunderstorms to the Mojave Desert. Some storms produced severe weather and flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Oil Well wildfire that started in the Kittridge Canyon area on the northeast side of Elko quickly spread eastward to the Osino area by gusty winds. The fire destroyed 7 homes, 5 outbuildings, and 16 vehicles. Smoke from the fire also closed down Interstate 80 for a couple of hours during the late afternoon hours of July 17 due to low visibility in smoke. The fire consumed a total of 7400 acres. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Oil Well wildfire that started in the Kittridge Canyon area on the northeast side of Elko quickly spread eastward to the Osino area by gusty winds. The fire destroyed 7 homes, 5 outbuildings, and 16 vehicles. Smoke from the fire also closed down Interstate 80 for a couple of hours due to low visibility in smoke. The fire consumed a total of 7400 acres.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wall of water, mud, rocks, debris, and small trees flowed down Lee Canyon Wash and overwhelmed culverts. Water and debris closed Highway 156 near mile marker 2.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A big push of monsoon moisture fueled an outbreak of thunderstorms over the Desert Southwest. Many storms in the Mojave Desert produced flash flooding and severe weather.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mud and debris flow caused the closure of the Ramsey Weeks Cutoff between Highway 50 and Alternate US 50 on the afternoon of the 24th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure near the northern California coast and daytime heating combined to bring strong to severe thunderstorms to the western Nevada Basin and Range on the 24th and 25th.
A thunderstorm produced downburst winds up to 79 mph at the Red Butte RAWS site in central Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eighteen power poles were snapped along Farm District Road, with short dry grass completely stripped from a nearby field. The wind gust was an estimate based on a utility company foreman's experience, who stated that it usually takes around 100 mph to snap power poles cleanly. Minor damage was reported to 4 homes and numerous billboards along Interstate 80 near mile marker 48, with moderate damage to 3 trucks and 2 outbuildings. Radar and damage patterns (examined by a NWS employee) did not indicate any rotation so straight-line winds are the most probable cause.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure near the northern California coast and daytime heating combined to bring strong to severe thunderstorms to the western Nevada Basin and Range on the 24th and 25th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water, rocks, and debris flowed over Highway 93 and many secondary roads in Pioche, and roads in Caselton were damaged by flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A big push of monsoon moisture fueled an outbreak of thunderstorms over the Desert Southwest. Many storms in the Mojave Desert produced flash flooding and severe weather.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nipton Road was closed in both directions near Searchlight, and Cottonwood Cove Road was closed due to extensive flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A big push of monsoon moisture fueled an outbreak of thunderstorms over the Desert Southwest. Many storms in the Mojave Desert produced flash flooding and severe weather.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud was photographed in the Gabbs Valley Range east of Hawthorne, with the position an estimate based on observed terrain features. It is possible that there was a tornado touchdown; however, terrain obscured the base of the funnel and no additional evidence was available.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure near the northern California coast and daytime heating combined to bring strong to severe thunderstorms to the western Nevada Basin and Range on the 24th and 25th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water two to three feet deep damaged Highway 375 3 miles NW of Rachel, and water got into basements of two residences in Rachel.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A big push of monsoon moisture fueled an outbreak of thunderstorms over the Desert Southwest. Many storms in the Mojave Desert produced flash flooding and severe weather.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five people died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Five people died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six people died of heat related causes in the Las Vegas Valley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Six people died of heat related causes in the Las Vegas Valley.
A push of monsoon moisture fueled an outbreak of thunderstorms with severe weather and flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain and hail contributed to a motorcycle crash on I-15 near mile marker 81. One man was killed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A push of monsoon moisture fueled an outbreak of thunderstorms with severe weather and flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A pulse thunderstorm produced a strong outflow that caused 3-foot whitecaps along Washoe Lake along with several snapped tree limbs 3___4 inches in diameter. Washoe Valley Mesonet reported a 59 MPH wind gust from 1625___1630PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Daytime heating and ample moisture beneath a strong ridge caused widespread convection over western Nevada and the eastern Sierra on August 3rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inches of water flowed over the road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A push of monsoon moisture fueled an outbreak of thunderstorms with severe weather and flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six people were rescued from the Flamingo Wash behind the Linq Hotel, and roads were closed in the area due to flooding. Two people were swept into the Flamingo Wash near Boulder Highway. One man, who had been rescuing people from the wash, was killed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A push of monsoon moisture fueled an outbreak of thunderstorms with severe weather and flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water and debris washed out Harris Springs Road, flowed along Highway 157 and Lovell Canyon Road, and through the Forest Service Campground and the Rainbow Subdivision. Flooding also closed Highway 160 at Tecopa Road, stranding about 100 cars on the highway until the water receded.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A push of monsoon moisture fueled an outbreak of thunderstorms with severe weather and flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported between Manhattan and Belmont. The road between Manhattan and Belmont  was washed out and needed repair. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported in Manhattan and Tonopah which caused damage to some roads.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred in the town of Tonopah damaging some road shoulders.  Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported in Manhattan and Tonopah which caused damage to some roads.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six people died of heat related causes in the Las Vegas Valley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Six people died of heat related causes in the Las Vegas Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary thunderstorm west-southwest of Pyramid Lake produced 1.25 inches of rain in less than an hour. The USGS stream gauge on Hardscrabble Creek registered a 5-foot rise in its level in about 40 minutes from 1515___1555PST. Nevada Department of Transporation reported debris and rocks on Nevada Highway 445 just south of Sutcliffe, Nevada, with all lanes blocked. No damage estimates were available.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed each afternoon August 6th___9th as an upper-level area of low pressure slowly moved into the Great Basin. Some of these thunderstorms produced strong wind gusts and flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary thunderstorm produced over 2 inches of rain and caused a debris flow across Nevada Highway 447 south of Gerlach, Nevada. Nevada Department of Transportation reported mud and debris in the roadway blocking all lanes in both directions. No damage estimates were available.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed each afternoon August 6th___9th as an upper-level area of low pressure slowly moved into the Great Basin. Some of these thunderstorms produced strong wind gusts and flash flooding.
Lingering monsoon moisture helped produce isolated thunderstorms over the southern Great Basin. One storm produced severe weather.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A road was washed out by a flash flood. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding washed out a road in the extreme southeast portion of Eureka county and damaged some roads near Eureka.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple roads in the area showed evidence of flash flooding. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding washed out a road in the extreme southeast portion of Eureka county and damaged some roads near Eureka.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A pulse thunderstorm produced a 53-knot peak gust at the Hot Springs Mountain HADS site.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed each afternoon August 6th___9th as an upper-level area of low pressure slowly moved into the Great Basin. Some of these thunderstorms produced strong wind gusts and flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Red Butte RAWS recorded a wind gust of 62 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm wind gust of 62 mph was reported at the Red Butte RAWS in Lander county and a thunderstorm wind gust of 61 mph was reported 8 miles north of Ryndon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained weather spotter estimated a thunderstorm wind gust of 61 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm wind gust of 62 mph was reported at the Red Butte RAWS in Lander county and a thunderstorm wind gust of 61 mph was reported 8 miles north of Ryndon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four people died of heat related causes in the Las Vegas Valley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Four people died of heat related causes in the Las Vegas Valley.
A weak push of monsoon moisture triggered isolated thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert. A few storms produced severe weather and flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five people died of heat related causes in the Las Vegas Valley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Five people died of heat related causes in the Las Vegas Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An area of pulse thunderstorms caused boulders to slide onto Nevada State Highway 28 at mile marker 3. No damage reports/estimates were available.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level area of low pressure near the California coast and a ridge axis over the eastern Great Basin combined to bring increased south to southeast flow into western Nevada and aided in producing a focusing mechanism for thunderstorms. These thunderstorms produced localized areas of heavy rainfall in far western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nevada Department of Transportation reported water over roadway along Interstate-580 and Damonte Ranch Parkway from a line of thunderstorms. Multiple vehicle accidents were reported, however, no estimate of damages were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level area of low pressure near the California coast and a ridge axis over the eastern Great Basin combined to bring increased south to southeast flow into western Nevada and aided in producing a focusing mechanism for thunderstorms. These thunderstorms produced localized areas of heavy rainfall in far western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One person died of heat related causes in the Las Vegas Valley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One person died of heat related causes in the Las Vegas Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One person at Fletcher View Campground had to be rescued by firefighters, and debris covered roads in a subdivision.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High heat and a little mid level moisture triggered isolated thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert. A few storms produced high winds in the deserts and flash flooding in the mountains.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tohakum 2 Fire burned 94,221 acres approximately 40 miles north of Nixon, Nevada, between August 29th and September 12th. No structures were lost, but power lines were damaged and traffic on Nevada 447 was affected by flames and smoke for several days, making travel difficult for Burning Man attendees headed to the Black Rock Desert. The fire was suspected to be started by a lightning strike from a high-based thunderstorm. The cost to fight the fire was at least $3.5M.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with limited rainfall produced many lightning strikes leading to several new wildfire starts in northwest Nevada and far eastern California on the 29th.
High heat and a little mid level moisture triggered isolated thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert. A few storms produced high winds in the deserts and flash flooding in the mountains.
High heat and a little mid level moisture triggered isolated thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert. A few storms produced high winds in the deserts and flash flooding in the mountains.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous people reported near zero visibility in Pahrump due to dust storm conditions associated with thunderstorm outflow winds.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High heat and a little mid level moisture triggered isolated thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert. A few storms produced high winds in the deserts and flash flooding in the mountains.
High heat and a little mid level moisture triggered isolated thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert. A few storms produced high winds in the deserts and flash flooding in the mountains.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tohakum 2 Fire burned 94,221 acres approximately 40 miles north of Nixon, Nevada, between August 29th and September 12th. No exact end time was found for this incident. No structures were lost, but power lines were damaged and traffic on Nevada 447 was affected by flames and smoke for several days, making travel difficult for Burning Man attendees headed to the Black Rock Desert. The fire was suspected to be started by a lightning strike from a high-based thunderstorm. The cost to fight the fire was at least $3.5M.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with limited rainfall produced many lightning strikes leading to several new wildfire starts in northwest Nevada and far eastern California on the 29th of August. The Tohakum 2 Fire which started in late August was not 100% contained until early September.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four people died of heat related causes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Four people in the Las Vegas Valley died of heat related causes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced strong winds near Cottonwood Cove. A man was killed when he became entangled in the mooring line of a house boat and dragged under the water.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoon moisture pushing west and north brought another round of thunderstorms to the Mojave Desert.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm wind gust of 61 mph was recorded at the Combs Canyon RAWS.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced a wind gust to 61 mph at the Combs Canyon RAWS.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An outflow from a line of thunderstorms produced a 57-knot peak gust at the KRNO ASOS. Airport observers also noted that visibility dropped to 3 statute miles south of the northward-moving gust front.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed each afternoon September 5th___6th as an upper-level area of low pressure off the California coast slowly moved into the Great Basin. Some of these thunderstorms produced strong wind gusts and hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong thunderstorm located near Lovelock Airport produced a wind gust of 59 knots.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed each afternoon September 5th___6th as an upper-level area of low pressure off the California coast slowly moved into the Great Basin. Some of these thunderstorms produced strong wind gusts and hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds knocked down power lines in Baker. Power was out through the night.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds downed power lines in Baker.
A thunderstorm produced a wind gust to 84 mph at the Cattle Camp RAWS.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 200-300 yard stretch of Highway 318 was flooded at Hiko.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong push of monsoon moisture plus low pressure moving in from the west triggered an outbreak of thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert with a few thunderstorms over the southern Great Basin. Several storms produced flash flooding and severe weather.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three people died of heat related causes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three people in the Las Vegas Valley died of Heat related causes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nipton Road was closed to Highway 95 due to flooding. This event continued into California.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud was photographed between Searchlight and Nelson Landing.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lander county sheriff's office reported flash flooding on state route 722 near Elkhorn Canyon Road. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Lander county sheriff's office reported flash flooding along state route 722 near Elkhorn Canyon Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: North Lake Tahoe Fire Protection District reported a confirmed tornado/waterspout a mile off the northeastern shore of Lake Tahoe near Sand Harbor, Nevada. The position of the tornado was estimated based on a video and terrain features. Numerous other spotter photos also showed a well-defined spray ring on the water surface of Lake Tahoe. The tornado was determined to be an EF-0 as no damage was reported. This tornado was associated with a supercell thunderstorm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong Thunderstorms developed over the Eastern Sierra and Northwestern Nevada on the afternoon of September 13th as an upper-level area of low pressure moved over south-central California.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: United States Forest Service employee reported a confirmed funnel cloud near the Rafter 7 Ranch. The funnel cloud was also photographed by Nevada Creeks and Communities at an event at Rafter 7 Ranch. The position was estimated based on the observation from the USFS employee.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong Thunderstorms developed over the Eastern Sierra and Northwestern Nevada on the afternoon of September 13th as an upper-level area of low pressure moved over south-central California.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted to 63 mph one mile SE of Lone Mountain and 71 mph two miles NNW of Centennial Hills.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system lingered near the California coast, helping to force isolated thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert. A couple of storms produced severe weather.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck at least two homes and started 10 tree fires.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system lingered near the California coast, helping to force isolated thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert. A couple of storms produced severe weather.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds partially blew off a roof on a mobile home in Battle Mountain. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds partially blew off the roof on a mobile home in Battle Mountain and downed some power and telephone lines in Elko.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds blew power and telephone lines down. Damages are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds partially blew off the roof on a mobile home in Battle Mountain and downed some power and telephone lines in Elko.

An early season winter-like storm brought heavy snow to portions of eastern Nevada.  Significant tree damage was reported in Ely and Ruth due to the heavy wet snow. In the Ruby Mountains up to 2 feet of snow was reported.

An early season winter-like storm brought heavy snow to portions of eastern Nevada.  Significant tree damage was reported in Ely and Ruth due to the heavy wet snow. In the Ruby Mountains up to 2 feet of snow was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A citizen reported a confirmed tornado/waterspout that formed two brief spin-ups on Lake Tahoe near Cave Rock, Nevada. The position of the tornado was estimated based on pictures and terrain features. The tornado was determined to be an EF-0 as no damage was reported. This tornado was non-supercellular in nature.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and isolated thunderstorms developed along a surface trough beneath an upper-level area of low pressure on September 21st.

The system brought high winds, significant snow, and rain to the Sierra Nevada and western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A dry slab avalanche occurred on Tamarack Peak within the Hourglass Bowl at 0900PST 16 November and partially buried a female skier and totally buried a male skier. A quote from the Sierra Avalanche Center: The person who was still skiing when the avalanche hit her was blown out of her skis and they were buried. She may have hit a tree and her back began seizing up. The person buried had both skis but lost a pole and one skin and had a torn ligament in his ankle. Therefore from this report, it is evident that both the skiers were injured in this avalanche.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The winter season's first strong atmospheric river moved slowly south from the Pacific Northwest coast between the 15th and the 16th before moving inland over northern California and Nevada on the 17th. The system brought high winds, significant snow, and rain to the Sierra Nevada and western Nevada.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure over the northeast Pacific on the 18th moved southeast, reaching northern California on the 19th. This system brought high winds and snowfall to the Sierra Nevada and western Nevada. Lake-enhanced snow showers developed the evening of the 19th behind the departing system. This enhancement was mainly confined to areas immediately southeast of Lake Tahoe, but the snow showers extended well south into Mono County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light snow occurred the morning and afternoon of 22 February. A crash was reported on Interstate 80 eastbound near the Mustang exit involving approximately 20 vehicles at approximately 1400PST 22 February according to Nevada Highway Patrol. Interstate 80 was closed from 1400PST to 1700PST 22 February. The Reno Gazette Journal reported 8 injuries from this crash. Nevada Highway Patrol reported that no cause was determined at the time of the accident.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave rounded the base of a longwave trough over the West Coast, passing over Northern California the morning of the 22nd. This shortwave brought snow to western Nevada throughout the 22nd.

According to the Nevada Highway Patrol, the cause was likely ice on the road from light snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant snow fell across northern Elko County, with the heaviest snow observed in the mountains and along State Route 225 from Adobe Summit through Owyhee. Montello also received significant snowfall in the eastern portion of the zone. Widespread 7 to 12 inches of snow fell in the valley locations, with 10-15 inches in the mountains. The snow was particularly heavy in Owyhee, where a frontal band stalled creating snowfall rates in excess of 1-2 inches per/hr.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to portions of northern and central Nevada. Some of the heavier snowfall amounts included 10 to 20 inches in Spring Creek and Lamoille, 14-17 inches in Eureka, and 7 inches in Ely. In addition, high winds gusting to 65 mph with the storm caused some property damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving upper level low dug into the western CONUS the 13th and moved inland over northern California and Nevada by the 17th. Shortwaves embedded in this low initially brought rain and high elevation snow to the Sierra Nevada and western Nevada. Colder air beneath the upper low allowed snow levels to fall, bringing widespread snow to the Sierra and western Nevada by the 16th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bands of heavy snow developed across southern Lander and Eureka Counties during the morning and afternoon of March 14th. Snow continued in southern Lander county into the 15th. Austin received 6.5 inches, with a two day total of 10 inches. Eureka picked up 7.5 inches of snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of winter storms impacted the Great Basin producing widespread light to moderate snowfall. Localized heavy snow occurred in Winnemucca and Golconda Summit, where 11-16 inches of snow was observed. Additionally, heavy snow fell across southern Lander and Eureka Counties. Snow amounts observed were 11-14 inches in Austin and Eureka. The heaviest snow fell from March 14th to 15th in central Nevada, and March 16th to 17th for northwestern Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A very localized heavy snow band formed and remained stationary over extreme southeast Humboldt County, including Golconda Summit and the town of Winnemucca. Significant localized snow amounts ranged from 11 inches around Winnemucca to 16 inches near Golconda Summit. This was a historic snow event for Winnemucca, breaking snowfall records.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of winter storms impacted the Great Basin producing widespread light to moderate snowfall. Localized heavy snow occurred in Winnemucca and Golconda Summit, where 11-16 inches of snow was observed. Additionally, heavy snow fell across southern Lander and Eureka Counties. Snow amounts observed were 11-14 inches in Austin and Eureka. The heaviest snow fell from March 14th to 15th in central Nevada, and March 16th to 17th for northwestern Nevada.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first part of this storm consisted of warm air advection precipitation that spread through the northern Sierra. The second part of this storm moved into the Sierra Nevada and western Nevada on the 21st and 22nd in the form of a fairly significant atmospheric river, tapping a deep plume of moisture moving in from the Eastern Pacific.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred 5 miles WNW of Rachel.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread light rain fell over much of southern Nevada due to an atmospheric river event. Strong winds surfaced where there were breaks in the rain, and there was one high wind report.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nevada Department of Transportation closed Mount Rose Highway (SR-431) from Fairview to Sky Tavern due to heavy snow and an avalanche. The avalanche was searched and cleared by the Mount Rose Ski Patrol to ensure that no other vehicles were involved.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: KOLO 8 Reno reported that Washoe County and the City of Reno closed Lemmon Drive from Deodar Way to Arkansas Drive 22 March 1700PST. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained weather spotter 4 miles south-southwest of Reno reported 0.65 inches of storm total rainfall from 6 April 0210PST to 7 April 1410PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and wet atmospheric river approached the west coast of the CONUS on the 5th, which brought gusty winds and significant rains to the Sierra and western Nevada the 6th through the 7th. In the foothills of western Nevada, rainfall amounts ranged from about a third of an inch to as much as three-quarters of an inch.  The valleys of the basin and range country in western Nevada saw generally less than half an inch, but the higher elevations received up to an inch or more.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station KSPZ, 2 miles west-southwest of Silver Springs (elevation 4269 feet) reported a 58 mph wind gust.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving spring storm moved into the Sierra Nevada late on the 15th and passed to the east late on the 16th. Gusty winds developed during the early morning hours of the 15th. The cold front associated with the system passed on the night of the 15th causing snow levels to rapidly fall. However, only light snow totals were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts occurred at a couple locations across northeastern Nye County. Wind gusts ranged from 65 MPH to 70 MPH.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds developed from a strong storm system moving through the Nevada during the days of April 15-16, 2018. Widespread strong winds were reported, but high winds were only recorded widespread across White Pine, southeastern Elko, and northeastern Nye Counties. Wind gusts in these areas were mostly in the 50-65 MPH range, with two locations seeing gusts to 70 MPH and 74 MPH. No reports of damage were received.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High wind gusts occurred across White Pine County. Wind gusts ranged from 74 MPH at Mather RAWS in the Snake range to 58 MPH at the Ely Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two people died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A dry microburst produced a wind gust to 67 MPH at the NWS Elko WFO. Other minor damage in town consisted of displaced shingles and a damaged fence. Blowing dust was also observed, but did not cause any significant impacts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dry thunderstorm developed across central Nevada and moved northward through the afternoon. The storm produced outflow winds over the Diamond Valley dry lake bed, which resulted in a dust storm. The dust storm moved into Elko and Spring Creek causing minor disruptions and impacts. The storm produced another dry microburst, resulting in a wind gust to 67 MPH in Elko and also produced minor damage throughout portions of town.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rain was a factor in a fatal car crash at 215 and Losee Rd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system passing over the Mojave Desert brought isolated impacts from rain and thunderstorms to the Las Vegas Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning damaged a home near Buffalo and Vegas Dr.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud was observed near the end of W Tropical Parkway.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two people died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter saw the funnel cloud touchdown, picking up debris from an open field. The estimated width of the tornado was approximately 25 yards. This occurred in a rural location - no damage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper level low situated across northern Nevada produced isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms on May 11th, 2018. The showers and thunderstorms produced two separate tornadoes. The first tornado occurred south of Interstate 80 near Golconda in an open field. The second tornado touched down north of Golconda off U.S. Highway 95 and crossed a dirt road. No damage was observed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained weather spotter saw a tornado briefly touchdown and move across a dirt road. No damage was reported.
