EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wave of rain showers passed through Pyramid Lake and brought northerly winds sustained to around 30 mph with gusts to 34 mph. A boater drowned at approximately 1030PST on 12 May when winds were determined to have peaked based on local observations near Sutcliffe along the shore of Pyramid Lake.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure centered over eastern Nevada brought bands of rain showers to western Nevada. Some of the stronger showers briefly kicked up northerly winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported a cold core funnel cloud over the Jackson Mountains.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper level low produced widespread showers and thunderstorms on May 15th, 2018. The showers and storms produced three separate funnel clouds across Lander and Humboldt Counties. The most notable funnel cloud occurred near Winnemucca, which garnered regional media attention as many people saw and took photos of the funnel cloud.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public spotted a cold core funnel cloud near Lewis Canyon in northern Lander County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A well defined rope cold core funnel was reported by numerous spotters. The funnel cloud garnered regional media attention and was viewed by numerous people.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CO-OP observer station CSVN2, Cold Springs Valley reported 1.16 inches of rainfall within a 24-hour period from 15 May 2300PST to 16 May 2300PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad area of upper level low pressure moved into the western part of the U.S. on the 16th and persisted through the 17th. This low brought greater forcing for showers and thunderstorms and produced a few strong storms across parts of Mineral County and the basin and range country on the 16th. The low also resulted in bands of moderate to heavy rain developing north of the main center of the low stretching across the northern Sierra and into far western Nevada on the 16th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golf ball size hail was reported by the public from a supercell thunderstorm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On May 16th and 17th, 2018 an upper level trough moved across northern Nevada, which produced showers and thunderstorms region wide. A few of the stronger storms became supercells over northeastern Nevada and produced hail, flash flooding, and gusty winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported nickel size hail. Photos showed significant hail accumulation impacting SR 225 north of Elko, Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported 0.50 inches of rainfall near the intersection of Prater and Sparks Blvd from 19 May 1605PST to 1705PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong thunderstorm developed over southern Washoe County during the early evening of the 19th producing brief heavy rainfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet C3920, 2 miles north-northeast of Sparks (elevation 4596 feet) reported 0.27 inches of rainfall within 15 minutes from 19 May 1633PST to 1648PST and 0.55 inches of rainfall within an hour from 19 May 1618PST to 1718PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong thunderstorm developed over southern Washoe County during the early evening of the 19th producing brief heavy rainfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station SMVN2, Smith Valley NOAWRC (elevation 4848 feet) reported 0.51 inches of rainfall in a two-hour period from 21 May 1640PST to 1840PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper low moved south over southern Nevada and persisted in that area through much of the 22nd, which caused showers and thunderstorms to become widespread across western Nevada and the eastern Sierra.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A collapsing core within a thunderstorm produced heavy rainfall over the Slinkard burn scar west of Topaz Lake, which caused two pronounced debris flows off the burn scar onto U.S. Highway 395 near the California/Nevada state line. The debris flows were up to 5 feet deep in a few places and closed the highway for over 18 hours while crews removed the flow. Nearly 200 people from the nearby Topaz Lodge were forced to the second floor as mud hit the exterior part of the first floor. No injuries were reported. No damage estimates were available from Topaz Lodge. The portable RAWS site above the Slinkard Fire burn scar (NCRC1; elevation 7451 feet) recorded 0.27 inches of rainfall in 15 minutes at the time two debris flows were reported (21 May 1727PST). A total of 0.90 inches of rainfall eventually fell on the burn scar in a two and a half hour time period from 21 May 1652PST to 1922PST. The cost to clear the debris flow for the Nevada Department of Transportation was a total of $51,476, which includes labor and equipment costs.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper low moved south over southern Nevada and persisted in that area through much of the 22nd, which caused showers and thunderstorms to become widespread across western Nevada and the eastern Sierra.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public provided a video showing what appears to be a well developed funnel cloud with a small dust whirl at the base. The tornado was estimated at an elevation around 6500 feet to 7000 feet. Location was estimated based on radar. Due to the remote location of the tornado, no damage was observed or surveyed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed low meandering across northern Nevada on May 22nd, 2018 prodcued weak showers and thunderstorms. One of the stronger thunderstorms produced a weak tornado across northern Elko County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: COOP observer station MINN2, Minden reported 0.58 inches of rainfall over a 24-hour period from 24 May 0500PST to 25 May 0500PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another low pressure system moved slowly from the central California coast to western Nevada on the 24th and 25th. This system produced two periods of showers and thunderstorms where rainfall totals were maximized across much of eastern California from Alpine County northward to Lassen County and western Nevada from Douglas County northward to the Oregon border. The first period occurred during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 24th, and the second occurred during the morning of the 25th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported via social media of water over Interstate 80 east of the Carlin Tunnel.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed low slowly meandered across the Nevada from May 26th to the 28th, producing widespread showers and thunderstorms. The storms were slow movers, resulting in flash flooding across portions of the area. The storm system also spawned a powerful supercell, which moved from northeast to southwest north of Elko and Carlin. A funnel cloud and well developed wall cloud was observed. Due to the radar signature, significant hail, strong winds, and a tornado were likely, but mostly stayed away from populated areas and were not reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant accumulating hail caused multiple accidents on Interstate 80 near the Carlin Tunnels.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained weather spotter reported a funnel cloud 5 miles north of Carlin. A NWS employee also reported a well developed wall cloud.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed low slowly meandered across the Nevada from May 26th to the 28th, producing widespread showers and thunderstorms. The storms were slow movers, resulting in flash flooding across portions of the area. The storm system also spawned a powerful supercell, which moved from northeast to southwest north of Elko and Carlin. A funnel cloud and well developed wall cloud was observed. Due to the radar signature, significant hail, strong winds, and a tornado were likely, but mostly stayed away from populated areas and were not reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A boat capsized near Lover's Cove in Lake Mead due to a combination of strong winds, high waves, and overloading.  All 17 people on board were rescued; three were injured.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of wind and overloading caused a boat to capsize in Lake Mead, injuring three people.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Martin Fire started in eastern Humboldt County and moved into western Elko County in northern Nevada. It became one of the largest fires in U.S. history with a final size at 435,569 acres. Impacts to grazing allotments, significant critical sage grouse habitat, and other unknown economic impacts were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A number of destructive wildfires burned across central and northern Nevada in July, which had significant economic impacts. Some of the impacts included, closed roads and highways, infrastructure impacts, damaged outbuildings, impacts to grazing, watersheds, and evacuations. Some of the more dustructive fires were the Martin, Echo, Hogan, Goose Creek, Dixie, Stag, Silverstate, Boone Springs, HD, Gregg, and Antelope.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nevada Department of Transportation reported that State Route 338 was closed in both directions from the California State Line to approximately Lyon County milepost 20 due to multiple debris flows. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Daytime heating and ample moisture along the periphery of a ridge caused scattered convection over western Nevada and the eastern Sierra July 19th through the 25th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Perry Fire southwest of Pyramid Lake burned 51,400 acres from 27 July 1622PST to 6 August 2100PST. Three residences and 15 other structures were damaged or destroyed. The fire cost at least $2.6 million dollars to fight. Microwave road was also closed during the fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Perry Wildfire started on the 27th with the cause listed as unknown/under investigation. By 5 August, it had burned 51,400 acres.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A debris flow from the Broad fire was reported over Fremont Road and approaching Manly Lane in Hadley and Carvers, Nevada.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of slow moving thunderstorms developed in central Nevada, causing localized heavy rain. The heaviest rainfall occurred in the higher terrain of northern Nye County.
Southerly flow pulled moisture into the Desert Southwest, fueling thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert. Many storms produced flash flooding and/or severe weather.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain over Duckwater, NV caused a debris flow over SR 379. The debris flow was estimated to be 5 to 7 feet wide and 2 inches deep.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of slow moving thunderstorms developed in central Nevada, causing localized heavy rain. The heaviest rainfall occurred in northern Nye County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Virginia Peak mesonet (elevation 8299 feet) reported a wind gust of 62 mph at 1545PST on 4 August.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds developed on the 4th due to a passing trough of low pressure. Gusts reached into the 35 to 45 mph range for many locations with mountaintop gusts in excess of 55 mph. Unfortunately, the stronger westerly winds also brought more smoke into the region from the west. This led to widespread poor air quality for parts of the day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria in Las Vegas.  During and immediately after the excessive heat event, ten people died of heat related causes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Timber Mountain RAWS gusted to 50 mph with thunderstorm outflows.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A decaying line of storms in central Nevada produced strong gusty outflow winds, which impacted the Timber Mountains in northern Nye County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds blew out several windows at the Riverside Hotel and also downed a few trees.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane John triggered a Gulf Surge, bringing scattered thunderstorms to the Mojave Desert, some of which produced severe weather and/or flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility dropped below a quarter mile in dust storm conditions. About 20 trees were blown down, at least one of which landed on a house. At least four power poles were blown down, two carport structures were damaged, shingles were blown off a house, there was damage to the exterior of a casino hotel, and an airplane at Henderson Executive Airport was tipped onto its nose.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane John triggered a Gulf Surge, bringing scattered thunderstorms to the Mojave Desert, some of which produced severe weather and/or flash flooding.
Hurricane John triggered a Gulf Surge, bringing scattered thunderstorms to the Mojave Desert, some of which produced severe weather and/or flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a transformer and started a backyard fire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding caused major damage to Nipton Road between mile markers 2 and 6. The road will be closed for months.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southerly flow pulled moisture into the Mojave Desert, fueling scattered thunderstorms. Some storms produced severe weather and/or flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced a dry microburst, resulting in a gust to 62 mph at the Combs Canyon RAWS.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms developed across the region with locally strong to severe thunderstorms.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four people died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highways 158 and 156 were closed due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The South Sugarloaf Fire burned 233,462 acres and destroyed at least two campgrounds. Additional structures were also damaged or destroyed, but exact numbers are not known. In addition to the structures, critical sage-grouse habitat, grazing, livestock, and wildlife habitat was either damaged/destroyed or threatened. One firefighter also sustained injuries while battling the fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms ignited a large and destructive wildfire in northern Nevada. The fire was called the South Sugarloaf Fire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The fire burned 59,789 acres across the Sheep Creek Range. Two firefighters were burned over sustaining injuries.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large wildfire burned across the Sheep Creek Range consuming 59,742 acres.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dirt berms were damaged, and rocks the size of basketballs were washed onto the road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southeasterly flow pulled monsoon moisture up into the eastern Mojave Desert, fueling scattered thunderstorms as far west as the Colorado River. One storm produced flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A suspected dust devil ripped an awning off a home and threw a piece of it into power lines, knocking out power to about 30,000 customers.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A suspected dust devil caused damage in Las Vegas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large and destructive wildfire burned in the Humboldt Toiyabe National Forest located in the Ruby Mountains. The fire was fanned by gusty winds and dry conditions with a majority of the burned total acreage occurring September 30th, 2018. Several buildings were lost with most of one campground destroyed. Monetary losses are unknown at this time, however the cost of suppressing the fire was in the millions. The final acreage was 9,169.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Gusty winds and dry conditions helped to fan a large and destructive fire in the Ruby Mountains. The fire was human caused and burned in the Humboldt Toiyabe National Forest.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS station NV-LY-19, 5 miles south-southeast of Silver Springs reported 0.81 inches of rainfall in a 24-hour period from 3 October 0700PST to 4 October 0700PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low moved across California and western Nevada providing forcing for showers and thunderstorm across the region. The combination of a moist atmosphere, instability and diffluent forcing from the low allowed for isolated storms with localized heavy rainfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding on Main Street in Pioche left water and debris in the street and water in several buildings.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific low pressure system plus leftover moisture from the remnants of Hurricane Rosa produced thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin. Some storms produced flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brief landspout tornado confirmed from the Callaghan Peak webcam.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Remnant moisture from tropical system Rosa was drawn north from an upper level low pressure system along California. The ample moisture aided in scattered to widespread showers and thunderstorms. The stronger storms produced gusty winds, small hail, heavy rain, and one landspout tornado.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thirty-six-hour snowfall amounts ranged from 2-4 inches at 6700 feet in Incline Village to as much as a 10 inches at higher elevations around Lake Tahoe (Mount Rose Ski Area).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The month of December started with a fast-moving upper level low and cold front sweeping east-southeast across north-central Nevada. These features brought snow to western Nevada and the Sierra Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CO-OP observer station VRCN2, Virginia City reported 8 inches of snow in a 24-hour period from 4 December 0800PST to 5 December 0800PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak warm air advection created light snow across the Sierra and northeast California during the late night hours of the 3rd and early morning hours of the 4th. Additional light snow developed on the afternoon and evening of the 4th and extended into the morning of the 5th as a weak deformation axis developed over the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twenty-four-hour snowfall amounts ranged from 1.4 inches at the Reno-Tahoe International Airport to 5 inches in northwest Reno and northern Reno. Spanish Springs and Sparks received between 1 to 3 inches of snowfall during the 24 hour period. Significant numbers of traffic accidents occurred in the Reno-Sparks area when temperatures rapidly cooled below freezing during the evening rush hour of Dec 4th. Areas within Carson City received 3 to 3.5 inches of snowfall, while the southwest portion of the Carson Valley received anywhere from 3 to 5 inches of snowfall during the 24 hour period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak warm air advection created light snow across the Sierra and northeast California during the late night hours of the 3rd and early morning hours of the 4th. Additional light snow developed on the afternoon and evening of the 4th and extended into the morning of the 5th as a weak deformation axis developed over the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twenty-four-hour snowfall amounts ranged from 1 to 2 inches at lake level in the Tahoe Basin to as much as 6 inches at the higher elevations around Lake Tahoe.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A suspected dust devil seen on home security cameras caused minor damage to a vehicle, blew down a fence, and threw objects around the back yard of a home.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A suspected dust devil was seen on security cameras doing minor damage around a home.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall amounts ranged from 3.9 inches at the Reno-Tahoe International Airport to 7.5 to 10.5 inches in northwest Reno and northern Reno. Spanish Springs and Sparks received between 2.5 to 8 inches of snowfall during the time period. Galena and Montreux received between 10 to 16 inches of snowfall during the time period. Areas within Carson City received 6 to 8 inches of snowfall during the time period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep shortwave trough over the eastern Pacific moved on shore the 5th and then spread through the Sierra Nevada and western Nevada the 6th and the 7th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall between 22 and 36 inches was reported in the higher elevations (generally above about 7000 feet MSL) of the Carson Range, with between 6 and 10 inches at lake level, between the 6th and the 7th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep shortwave trough over the eastern Pacific moved on shore the 5th and then spread through the Sierra Nevada and western Nevada the 6th and the 7th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense freezing fog formed during the overnight hours Friday and persisted into Saturday morning.  A driver heading southbound on US Highway 93 about fourteen miles north of Wells, Nevada tried to pass a slower moving vehicle on the two lane road but crashed head-on with a northbound truck.  There was one fatality and one critical injury.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistent areas of freezing fog with the visibility reduced to near zero at times resulted in a collision between two cars.

High winds ahead of the main upper level wave developed the 25th before a series of shortwaves brought strong downslope winds, snow, and spillover rainfall to western Nevada.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Meadow Valley Wash flooded and closed Highway 322. The flooding continued for a couple of days until the wash receded.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public sent in picture of well developed cold air funnel. No ground circulation present.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent and cold area of low pressure, along with a moist atmosphere, provided a conducive environment for the formation of cold air funnels across northern and central Nevada during the end of May 2019.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lander County Sheriff's office and members of the public (through Facebook) reported a cold air funnel one mile north of Argenta. Numerous photos confirm cold air funnel did not touch the ground.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent and cold area of low pressure, along with a moist atmosphere, provided a conducive environment for the formation of cold air funnels across northern and central Nevada during the end of May 2019.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public saw a cold air funnel approximately 3 miles north of Emigrant Pass while driving eastbound on I-80.  The cold air funnel did not touch down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent and cold area of low pressure, along with a moist atmosphere, provided a conducive environment for the formation of cold air funnels across northern and central Nevada during the end of May 2019.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public (through Facebook) reported a cold air funnel near Crescent Valley.  The cold air funnel did not touch down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent and cold area of low pressure, along with a moist atmosphere, provided a conducive environment for the formation of cold air funnels across northern and central Nevada during the end of May 2019.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water from rain showers combined with an above normal snowpack to produce runoff into Salmon Falls Creek.  The creek rose in height to approximately 11 feet at the USGS gauge, causing the parking area at the rest stop to close.  Water eventually receded from the rest stop and it was reopened.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A melting snowpack combined with periods of rain to produce increased runoff into area creeks and rivers.  Given how slow rises are in northern Nevada, some of the floods last for weeks.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported a rope funnel cloud 5 miles west of US Highway 93 near Palomino Hills. NO ground circulation was seen and funnel lasted about 5 minutes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper level low pressure spinning across central Nevada helped provide the right environment for cold air funnel formation.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm dropped pea-sized hail, approximately two inches deep, over an area causing damage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced two inch deep hail in Diamond Valley, Eureka county.  The size of the hail was about pea-sized.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Increased runoff due to snowmelt and precipitation brought high flows to the Humboldt River.  This caused the floodplain to become saturated.  State Route 795 (also called Reinhart Lane) was closed as a preventative measure to prevent the road's foundation from cracking due to the weakened road foundation.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An above average snowpack, combined with a wet month of May, produced additional runoff into area creeks and rivers.  This slow, but continuous, runoff brought river levels to minor to moderate flood stage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jasper Fire in northern Sun Valley burned 1,165 acres from 13 July 1400PST to 16 July 1700PST. Sierra Front Dispatch Center stated that one home and two outbuildings were destroyed. At one point more than 100 homes were threatened, and the Washoe County Sheriff___s Office was going door-to-door urging people to evacuate. Firefighting costs were approximately $769K USD according to the Nevada Bureau of Land Management.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A longwave trough moved across the northwestern US the 13th through the 17th. This trough brought breezy conditions each afternoon to western Nevada and eastern California.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 9-year-old Reno girl died on 19 July from injuries she suffered when strong winds blew an inflatable bounce house with three children inside into power lines.  The Washoe County Sheriff's Office says the bounce house was uplifted about 10 feet and got caught on the lines in a south Reno neighborhood. Deputies and firefighters rescued the children. They treated two for minor injuries at the scene and transported the 9-year-old girl to the hospital, where she succumbed to her injuries 19 July. The incident occurred on the afternoon of 14 July around 1500PST. Authorities told KOLO-TV the bounce house seemed to be secured to the ground but was caught by an especially strong gust of wind. Winds were sustained 15-20 mph with gusts 20-25 mph at nearby Reno-Tahoe International Airport around the incident time.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A longwave trough moved across the northwestern US the 13th through the 17th. This trough brought breezy conditions each afternoon to western Nevada and eastern California.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three people died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three people died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong outflow winds from nearby decaying thunderstorms blew a small tree down, blew the siding of a single-wide trailer off, blew metal roofing panels off another single-wide trailer, and damaged a metal overhang on a flat-roofed store. Wind gusts were estimated to be 50-55 mph. The damage was estimated based upon the costs of the materials damaged.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms formed across parts of west-central Nevada, moving quickly northward into northern Nevada. The strongest storms produced wind gusts between 45 and 50 mph and blowing dust across parts of the basin and range.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station C4390, 3 miles east-northeast of Carson City (elevation 4619 feet) reported 0.69 inches of rainfall in a 1-hour period from 26 July 1417PST to 1517PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from the eastern Pacific Ocean and the Gulf of California moved northward around the periphery of high pressure centered over the Four-Corners region of the Rockies the 24th into the 25th. This moisture, coupled with the weak flow and increased instability in the lower to middle portions of the atmosphere, resulted in storms producing heavy rains.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station EW5237 3 miles northwest of Stead (elevation 5007 feet) reported 1.02 inches of rainfall in just over a 3-hour time period from 25 July 1530PST to 1846PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from the eastern Pacific Ocean and the Gulf of California moved northward around the periphery of high pressure centered over the Four-Corners region of the Rockies the 24th into the 25th. This moisture, coupled with the weak flow and increased instability in the lower to middle portions of the atmosphere, resulted in storms producing heavy rains.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Washoe County Official reported that runoff from thunderstorms caused flash flooding near Swan Lake. A nearby RAWS approximately 3 miles to the east of the flooded area reported 1.53 inches of rainfall in a 3-hour period from 25 July 1640PST to 1940PST. No damage or cleanup information was available.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from the eastern Pacific Ocean and the Gulf of California moved northward around the periphery of high pressure centered over the Four-Corners region of the Rockies the 24th into the 25th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: KTVN Channel 2 News reported that the roof on Reed High School leaked during heavy rainfall from thunderstorms on the afternoon of 25 July. A nearby mesonet reported 0.21 inches of rainfall from 1703PST to 1803PST. According to Washoe County School District, three sections of the roof were being replaced at the time. All three sections leaked in multiple areas. Walls, ceilings, floors, and 36 computers were damaged by the rain water. Preliminary damage estimates were $40-60K according to the school district.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from the eastern Pacific Ocean and the Gulf of California moved northward around the periphery of high pressure centered over the Four-Corners region of the Rockies the 24th into the 25th. This moisture, coupled with the weak flow and increased instability in the lower to middle portions of the atmosphere, resulted in storms producing heavy rains.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained weather spotter reported mud and water over the railroad tracks at Gold Hill. A nearby mesonet in Virginia City reported 0.28 inches of rainfall from 26 July 1400PST to 1451PST. No damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from the eastern Pacific Ocean and the Gulf of California moved northward around the periphery of high pressure centered over the Four-Corners region of the Rockies the 24th into the 25th. This moisture, coupled with the weak flow and increased instability in the lower to middle portions of the atmosphere, resulted in storms producing heavy rains.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One person died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One person died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached in Las Vegas. One person died two days later of heat related causes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached in Las Vegas on July 29th. One person died two days later of heat related causes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds downed two trees at the intersection of Rainbow and Erie in Las Vegas.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A brief intrusion of monsoon moisture brought spotty thunderstorms to the Mojave Desert. A couple of strong storms caused wind damage and flooding in the Las Vegas Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to eight inches of water flowed through the intersection of Blue Diamond and Rainbow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A brief intrusion of monsoon moisture brought spotty thunderstorms to the Mojave Desert. A couple of strong storms caused wind damage and flooding in the Las Vegas Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several hours after a thunderstorm, water flowing through a wash overcame a berm and spilled into a neighborhood. Cars were stranded, and the water was waist deep in places. Water neared, but did not enter, homes. It took until the next morning for the water to recede (thus, this event continued into August).
